William Hughes.

ELIZABETH HUGHES . I am the wife of William Hughes—the prisonen had furnished rooms of mine—they came as brother and sister—about three weeks ago Harrild told me she was going out nursing, but her lady would soon be well, and she should soon be back again—she went away
Watson continued to occupy his room—I looked through the key holes—they were blocked up—I got a policeman, and found the feathers gone ont of one bed, and nearly from the other, and the sheets and fire-irons gone out of both the rooms—Watson said he was a custom-house officer, but he did nothing—he never went out—Harrild paid for both rooms—these are my things—the rooms are next to each other.

JOSEPH LUCAS HODGES . I am shopman to Mr. Clay, a pawnbroker, in the New-road—I have a pillow, pledged in August, 1841, for 1s., and an
other pawned in April, in the name of Ann Watson—I cannot swear by whom.
GEORGE SMELLIE . I produce a pillow, pledged on the 10th of June, in the name of Ann Watson.
HENRY WATTS . I produce two pillows—I cannot say by whom they were pledged.
CHARLES WILTSHIRE . I produce a pillow, which was pawned in the name of Ann Watson, by Harrild.

WILLIAM NICHOLLS (police-constable K 117.) On the 16th of October I found the prisoners in Lucas-street—I said I wanted them for robbing Mrs. Hughes—Harrild said to Watson, "What do you mean to do?"—he said nothing—I found on Watson a key, with the end filed off, and nine
teen duplicates, five of which relate to the property.

Watson's Defence, The things in the room were not of the value they put on them. I had no intention to make away with them; I had been ill nearly two years, and lost the use of my side; when we took the rooms, the prosecutor promised us work; we had the rooms nearly seventeen months, and I paid nearly 2l. for rent.

Harrild's Defence. I took the room at 2s. a week; the landlady has been very disagreeable, because she was connected with a fortune-teller; she has a person comes to see her, though her husband is continually in the house. I have got a bad husband, who has turned me out of doors, and urged me to prostitute myself, instead of which I pawned these things.

WATSON—
GUILTY . Aged 43.

HARRILD—
GUILTY . Aged 26.
Confined One Year.
(There was another indictment against Harrild.)

3011.
AUGUSTUS SYLVANDER was indicted
for stealing, on the 21st of October, 4 sovereigns, the monies of
Richard Brewer Ley, from his person.

RICHARD BREWER LEY . I am a seaman, lodging at Mr. Boyle's, in White Horse-place. On the 21st of October I went up stairs to lay down after dinner—I had a paper containing four sovereigns—I pot them into my fob—when I went to bed no one was in the room—when I awoke I missed my sovereigns.

CHARLES BOYLE . I keep this house—the prosecutor bad been drink
ing, and went to lay down—the prisoner lodged there, and he went up stairs to lay down too—he came down again in a quarter of an hour—no one else went up during that time—the prisoner said he would go out and buy a bit of soap, and a pint of half-and-half—I said he had only 1s., which I had let him have in the morning—soon after I heard the pro
secutor had been robbed—I went after the prisoner, and found him in the King William, treating a young woman with brandy-and-water—I followed him to a baker's-shop next door, and saw him counting his money—there was 4s. 6d., and some other money, which I thought was two farthings, in a paper—I got him home with a great deal of trouble—he was very abusive—I examined the paper, and found it had two so
vereigns in it.

JOHN RANSOM (police-constable K 328.) I went to the house—I saw Boyle and the prisoner behind him—I held my lamp in the direction of the prisoner's legs, and he dropped a piece of paper—Mr. Boyle picked it up, and it contained two sovereigns—he gave the prisoner in charge.

GUILTY . Aged 33.—
Confined Three Months.

3012.
HENRY TAYLOR and
JAMES NOWLAND were indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of October, 2 tar barrels, value 6s., the goods of
William Smith Brown.
WILLIAM HENRY PEACOCK . I am foreman to Mr. William Smith

Brown, of Broad-street, Ratcliff, we had twenty-four empty tar-barrels, on the 12th of October—I saw them safe that evening—on the following morning, about seven o'clock, I missed two of them—I hare seen them since—they were my master's.

FRANCIS GOWRAN (police-constable K 258.) About twenty minutes before six o'clock in the morning, on the 13th of October, I saw the pri
soners in Butcher-row, and then down Rat cliff-cross—they then returned to Broad-street, and watched about Mr. Brown's—I watched them—they went in, and in a few minutes they came out, each rolling a tar-barrel from the premises.
Taylor's Defence. A man in a fustian jacket asked roe if I would take a tar-barrel to White Horse-street, Stepney.
(Nowland received a good character.)

TAYLOR—
GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Four Months.

NOWLAND)—
GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.

3013.
JOHN LEE was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of October, 3 1/4 lbs. weight of flour, value 7d., the goods of
Samuel Lancaster, his master.

SAMUEL LANCASTER . I am a baker, and live at Kensington, the pri
soner was in my employ. On the 20th of October I gave him twenty
one half-quartern bags to fill with flour, he brought me but twenty back—I waited a little while—he went out with his bread—I then looked round the bakehouse, and found two half-quartern bags filled with flour, behind three tins—I said nothing—the prisoner came back from serving a few customers, and went into the bakehouse—in about five minutes he went out again—I looked, and the bags were gone—I told the officer to go and take him—the bags were found on him.
RICHARD TRIPP (police-constable T 84.) I took the prisoner, and found the bags of flour in his hat.
Prisoner. I went to the bakehouse, and came out directly. I was not there two minutes. I was nearly a quarter of a mile from the shop when he found them in my hat.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Six Months.

3014.
LOUISA ACOX was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of Oc
tober, I apron, value 1s., the goods of
Elizabeth Trevor.

ELIZABETH TREVOR . I am housekeeper to Mr. Bates, of Portland-place. I went into the country—the prisoner was engaged to take charge of the country house, and when she left a number of articles were missing, and amongst them my apron—this is it.
Prisoner. The apron was amongst my clothes; it came home from the wash; the other house-maid put it among my things.
NOT GUILTY .

3015.
LOUISA ACOX was again indicted
for stealing, on the 6th of October, I thermometer and frame and case, value 15s., the goods of
Spen
cer Joshua Alwyne, Marquis of Northampton.

DAVID DAVIS . I am under butler to Spencer Joshua Alwyne, Marquis of Northampton. The prisoner lived there as house-maid about twelve months ago—I missed several things, and, amongst the rest, a thermometer and frame and case, from the study—the case is here, but the frame and
the thermometer are gone—I believe this case to be the Marquis's, but I could not swear to it—I missed it about a month after the prisoner left.
JURY. Q. Was this perfect the last time you saw it? A. Yes—this is not the crest of the Marquis which is on it.
GEORGE ROGERS . I am a police-officer. I took the prisoner—I searched her room and box, and found this frame.
Prisoner's Defence. It was among some dust. It was throwing about some time in our room; I did not know it was of any consequence.

GUILTY . Aged 38.—
Confined Nine Months.

3016.
MARIA HARRISON was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of October, I sovereign, 3 half-crowns, 3 shillings, 2 sixpences, and I groat, the monies of
Thomas Henwood, from his person.

THOMAS HENWOOD . I live in Quebec-street, St. Marylebone, and am a carpenter. On the 24th of October I went to a public-house, where I staid till a quarter past twelve o'clock at night—the prisoner was there—we drank together, and then left—the prisoner came away with my nephew sod me—I told my nephew not to leave me—we turned down Portman
square and down Oxford-street—I was the worse for liquor—I then went to an archway, for a certain purpose, leaving my nephew and the prisoner standing on the pavement—when I came back she was gone—my nephew said, "Have you got your watch?"—I said, "Yes"—I then missed my money—I lost about 1l. 12s.—I know I had a sovereign and three half-crowns, a shilling, and some sixpences, and a fourpenny piece in my pocket—I sent Ruddy to find where she lived—he brought her to me next evening, but nothing was found on her.
GEORGE SMITH . I am the prosecutor's nephew. As he was walking along, I did not see the prisoner put her hand in his pocket, but she was rummaging about his trowsers.

WILLIAM RUDDY . I went to the Three Tuns—I saw the prosecutor and the prisoner in company there—we came out at a quarter after twelve o'clock, and I wished him good night—next morning he sent to me to say she had robbed him—I found her, and told her I had come about Mr. Hen
wood's case, and that she had robbed him of 1l. 12l. or 1l. 14s.—she said she had not taken so much, only a sovereign—I asked if she had any money left—she said no, she had bought a shawl and various things with it.
Prisoner. He gave me a sovereign, and that I bought the shawl with.

THOMAS HENWOOD
re-examined. On my oath, I did not give it her—I was the worse for liquor—my little boy sat facing me all the time—she asked me to give her a pint of beer, and, to the best of my knowledge, I gave her a pint of half-and-half, and then I gave her something to eat.
NOT GUILTY .

3017.
HENRY SMITH was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of Oc
tober, 1 cap, value 5s.; and 1 handkerchief, value 3s.; the goods of
Ste
phen Jarman, in a vessel in a port of entry and discharge.

STEPHEN JARMAN . I am a seaman on board the barque Emma, which was lying in the St. katherine's Docks. On the 24th of October the pri
soner was on board—I saw him closing the lid of my chest—I saw a hand
kerchief lying on the cabin floor—I asked what he had been doing at the chest—he said to get some bread—I looked, and missed the cap and hand
kerchief

—I saw something under his trowsers, gave him in charge, and the cap was found on him—this is my cap and handkerchief—he had'no busi
ness with them, nor at my box—he did not belong to the vessel.

Prisoner. A man was coming up the forecastle—I asked him to give me something to eat—he said I might go down and get something—I went down and helped myself to a bit of bread; the cap and handkerchief laid in one of the bed places.

GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Confined Six Months.

3018.
JOHN WOOD was indicted
for stealing, on the 22nd of October, 1 pair of trowsers, value 1l., the goods of
John Taylor and an
other.

THOMAS TAYLOR . I am in partnership with John Taylor, of Tottenham Court-road. About a quarter before eight o'clock, on the night of the 22nd of October, I saw the prisoner take a pair of trowsers off the rail—I fol
lowed—he was brought back and given into custody—the trowsers were picked up about two doors off, and brought back to the shop—I did not see the prisoner throw them down, but I saw him take them.
Cross-examined by MR. ESPINASSE. Q. Have you any other Dime? A. No—these trowsers hung on a rail outside the shop—when he took them my face was towards him.

WILLIAM GILBERT (police-constable E 136.) I took the pritouer—he said if I would let him go he would never do the like again. The prisoner received a good character, and a witness engaged to em
ploy him.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Nine Days.

3019.
JOHN ARMSTRONG was indicted
for stealing, on the 14th of October, 2 spoons, value 1l., the goods of
Benjamin Baker.

FREDERICK BAKER . I live with my father, benjamin Baker, at Stnt
ford. We had two silver spoons safe on the 14th of October—one was in the kitchen, and the other lying in the yard, by the back-door—we missed them—this produced is one of them—I saw the prisoner on our premises the day before—my brother was there that day, and we missed him as well as the spoons.

Cross-examined. Q. One of the spoons had been taken out of the kitchen? A. Yes—I do not know who by—I saw the spoons between four and six o'clock on Friday, the 14th, and missed them the next day—the one that was lying at the back-door was not seen again till I found it at the silversmith's—my brother has been to sea.
COURT. Q. Have you charged your brother with stealing these? Yes—the prisoner was a friend of his.
WILLIAM VELLENWITH . I am shopman to Mr. Midrileton; he lives in the Commercial-road. I bought this spoon of a young man—I cannot say that it was the prisoner.
ROBERT HARRILE . I live in the Commercial-road. I bought a silver table-spoon, similar to this one, of the prisoner.

JOHN CAVERLEY (police-constable K 203.) I took the prisoner on the Bow-road—be passed—I called him by his name—my brother officer told him he was charged with robbing Mr. Baker of two spoons—he said it was the first he had heard of it.
NOT GUILTY .

3020.
ROBERT SHORE was indicted
for stealing, on the 26th of September, 1 table, value 10s., the goods of
Elizabeth Robinson.

ELIZABETH ROBINSON . I live in Corporation-row, Clerkenwell—I hired a room of Mrs. Burgess in August last, and furnished it—I was to hare been married to the prisoner next Christmas—I had a table in the room, a bed, and four blankets—I did not authorize him to take any of them away.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. YOU hired the room to deposit the furniture? A. Yes—the prisoner helped me to take the bed and pillow, but not the table—he has married my sister instead of me—I had only been to Mrs. Burgess with him once about these things—I have had no dif
ference with him—I am not on bad terms with my sister—I have several times been in a house in Brunswick-street, St. John's-street-road—my sister lodged there—I do not know Fielding—I never was there when any conversation took place between me and the prisoner—I swear I never said anything to him about taking these goods to another place—he bor
rowed a sovereign of me, and he said he could make five or ten shillings—it was not got from me on account of these goods—the banns were put up for our marriage by Fielding—there was no difference with the prisoner and me after that.

MARY ANN BURGESS . I am the wife of Joseph Burgess—the prisoner came to me on the Saturday, and brought me the week's rent, and said Mrs. Robinson had sent it—the table was in my parlour, and the prisoner took it away—he also took the bed and bedding—he said Miss Robinson had sent him for it.

SAMUEL FIELDING . I live in Brunswick-street, St. John's-street-road—I know the prisoner and the prosecutrix—she has frequently come to my house—I remember her being in my room with the prisoner—some con
versation took place about this furniture, and she authorised him to take the things from where they were deposited, and put them where he thought proper, till they were married—I pot up the banns for their mar
riage—it was after that that the goods were moved.
COURT. Q. When was it that conversation took place? A, I think about ten weeks ago—I cannot state the day.

ELIZABETH ROBINSON
re-examned. When he was going to marry me he took the goods for me, with the exception of the table—I never autho
rised him to take the table—he married my sister about a fortnight after taking the goods.

GUILTY . Aged 40.—
Transported for Seven Years.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

3021.
JOSEPH FOOKES was indicted
for embezzlement.

JOHN GRAY . I keep the White Hart in the Mile End-road—the pri
soner was my barman about four months—he received money from my different customers—when he received it he ought to have put it in the till, or on the hob—on the 8th of October he did not account to me for 1s. 4d. for gin, that had been sold—I examined my till that day—I found no sovereign in it—he was not authorised to put any money into his pocket.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q, It was not usual to account for the sale of particular portions of liquor? A. Certainly not—I ex
pected, if anything was sold, that the money should be put into the till—there generally is enough money in the till to give change—I had told him there was a great deficiency in beer and gin—the policeman saw him at half-past eleven—I had seen the till three or four times in the course of the half hour, for I was putting marked money in—I cannot tell how much was in the till or on the hob at half-past eleven—I was clearing the till as fast as possible.

MR. ESPINASSE. Q. Can you say, on the 8th of October, whether there was sufficient in the till or on the hob to give change for the sore
reign? A. I should say there was.

EDWARD WANDERER TOWNSON (police-constable K 143.) I was at Mr. Gray's at half-past eleven in the morning—I saw the prisoner serving at the bar—I saw Mrs. Thompson go in—she called for a pint of gin—the pri
oner served her—she gave him a sovereign—he put it into his waistcoat
pocket, took some change from his pocket, and gave her—I watched him for twenty minutes after the woman went away, to see if he appropriated it to the till—he did not—Thompson came back, and he gave her a 6d. which he took from the till—I took him into custody, and cautioned him against saying anything—I asked where he got the money—he said, from Mr. Gray—Mr. Gray gave him the shilling—he did not say anything about this—another officer found a sovereign.

ANN THOMPSON . On the 8th of October I went to Mr. Gray's for a pint of gin—it came to 1s. 4d.—the prisoner served me—I gave him a sovereign—he put it into his left hand trowsers' pocket—he gave me one half sovereign, and the rest in silver, out of his pocket—he gave me 6d. short at first, and then he gave it me out of the till.
HENRY JOHN PARKER (police-constable K 10.) I asked the prisoner what money he had about him—he said "A sovereign, two shillings, and two sixpences."

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Nine Months.
(There were two other indictments against the prisoner.)

3022.
ELIZA WILLIAMS was indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of October, 2lbs. 10oz. weight of ham, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
John Loveridge.
ELIZABETH JEFFRIES . I live in Shouldham-street. On Wednesday afternoon, the 19th of October, I saw the prisoner take a piece of ham from the prosecutor's shop.

CHARLOTTE GILES . The prisoner came to my room that day, and asked me to let her stop for a few minutes, she would make me a recom
pense—I pushed her down stairs, and the prosecutor stood there with the ham in his hand.
RICHARD LOVERIDGE . I am the son of John Loveridge. I followed the prisoner up to this place, and saw her throw this ham away—I stood till she came out, and I took her—it was my father's.
Prisoner's Defence. Distress caused me to do it.

GUILTY . Aged 40.—
Confined Three Months.

3023.
SARAH MARTIN was indicted
for stealing, on the 26th of October, 11 eggs, value 7d.; and 1 1/4 lbs, weight of beef, Value 1s., the goods of
Robert Armstrong.

CHARLES COCKBURN . I am servant to Robert Armstrong, of Crawford-street, Marylebone—the prisoner was his char-woman. About twelve o'clock on the 26th of October, I went to a drawer, and saw twelve eggs in it—I afterwards went to look for them, and missed eleven—I went after her to another shop—she put her basket down—I took it up, and found in it the eggs and the meat.
Prisoners Defence. They gave me the cold meat.

GUILTY. Aged 50.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Ten Days.

3024.
ROBERT LOCK was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of Octo
ber, 2 tame fowls, value 3s., the goods of
George Pope.
GEORGE POPE . On Tuesday evening I was called—I found the officer and the prisoner at the counter, with three fowls—I said one of them was mine—I missed two—I cannot swear to these two.
WILLIAM NICHOLLS and EDWARD KELL being called, did not appear.
NOT GUILTY .

3025.
MARK MALONY was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of October, one shawl, value 8s., the goods of
Mary Ward, from her person.
The prosecutrix did not appear.
NOT GUILTY .

3026.
HENRY WARD was indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of Octo
ber, 17 feet of leaden pipe, value 5s., the goods of
Thomas Smith; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

EDWARD WATSON . I am foreman to Thomas Smith, and live in Derby-road. I went to a building of his, and found a quantity of leaden pipe there—it was his, and was safe on the afternoon of Saturday, the 16th of October.

JAMES BRANNAN (police-constable N 69.) I was on duty in plain clothes, about half-past one o'clock in Beauvoir-square, near an unfinished house—I watched about half an hour, and saw the prisoner come down the stairs with this pipe in his arms, and two pieces I took from his pocket. EPHRAIM GRANT (police-constable S 144.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from the Clerk of the Peace for Surrey—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 34.—
Transported for Seven Years.

3027.
WILLIAM JORDAN was indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of October, 2 shillings, the monies of
George Webb, his master.

GEORGE WEBB. I am the prisoner's master. On the 19th of October, I marked two shillings, and put them into the till at a quarter before eight o'clock in the evening—soon after, Mrs. Zimmerman's servant came in for some butter—I went to the till soon after, and found the two shillings gone—the policeman searched the prisoner, and found one in his pocket—I do not know what has become of the other.
Cross-examined by MR. PATNE. Q. YOU were only five minutes absent? A. Yes—the prisoner had been only five weeks in my service.
JOHN FREDERICK ZIMMERMAN . I went to the prosecutor's shop—I did not receive any shilling from the prisoner—this other shilling has my mark on it, which Gregory, my man, paid there.

Cross-examined. Q. What is the mark on this other shilling? A. A mark under the chin with the point of a nail—it enables me to swear to it—I gave it to Joseph Gregory, my shopman, from half-past seven till a quarter to eight o'clock.
WILLIAM TILLIER (police-constable C 28.) I was called and searched the prisoner—I found two shillings on him, which I now produce.
JOSEPH GREGORY . I paid this shilling to the prisoner.
Cross-examined. Q. You did not see what was done with it? A. I did not.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 21.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Four Months,

3028.
ALEXANDER BRESLER was indicted
for a misdemeanor. Upon which no evidence was offered.
NOT GUILTY .

3029.
JOHN WILSON was indicted
for a misdemeanor.

JOHN TANNER . I keep an outfitter's shop in the Minories. The pri
soner came and represented himself to keep a tailor's and outfitter's shop—he said he had to get a chest of drawers and a washing-stand for Captain Clark—that he lived at No. 6, Lincoln's Inn-fields, and we were to make the drawers—he said he was making clothes for Captain Clark—I said I should like to see Captain Clark, in case he would like any alteration—he came again in a day or two, with a drawing of the drawers and a signa
ture—I got on with them, and he ordered me to send them a week after
wards—believing that he had an order from Captain Clark, I sent these things—I have inquired, and found the prisoner keeps a cabinet-maker's shop in Lincoln's Inn-fields, not a tailor's and outfitter's—I have not found Captain Clark.

WILLIAM WORFORD . I am a blacksmith, living at Croydon. I was employed by the prosecutor to carry the drawers on the 14th of Septem
ber to No. 6, Lincoln's Inn-fields—it was a lawyer's chambers—I made Inquiries, and could find no such person—I returned with the drawers, and on the 16th I went there, and the prosecutor said, "I have sent two boys with the drawers; I want you to go and see them delivered safe"—I went, and saw one of the boys with a truck—the prisoner was pushing behind—he said, "How is it you did not bring them up last Wednesday?"—I said, "I was up here, but could not find you"—he said, "It is up here, and it was No. 6, Bear-yard—there was no shop at No. 6, Lincoln's Inn-fields.

WILLIAM PRIEST . I live in the Strand. The prisoner came and asked if I purchased any articles—he said he was a cabinet-maker—I and I did, but did not want any—he called again, and said he had an article at the house in Bear-yard, and I bought these drawers of him for 5l.

Prisoner's Defence. I had orders from Captain Clark for a chest of drawers; Mr. Tanner sent them home; they were not made to order, and the gen
tleman would not have them.

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Confined Nine Months.

3030.
PATRICK MARD was indicted
for a misdemeanor.

THOMAS HANDLEY . I am foreman to George Bird, a builder, in Edge
ware-road—the prisoner was employed on the sewers there. On 22nd of September I discharged him, and gave him a note for 11s. 6d.—on the

Saturday morning following he came to the works, and asked me to ac
commodate him, because it was nearly two miles to go to my employers—I said I would pay him the money, and asked for the note that I gave him—he said he had lost it—I paid him 7s. 6d. and 4s.—he went away with it—this is the note I gave him.

FRANCIS WATSON . I am clerk to George Bird. On the morning of the 24th of September the prisoner came and produced this note—I paid him three half-crowns, and four shillings, which was the amount of his wages—if he had not brought me that note I should not have paid him.

Prisoner's Defence. In January last Handley borrowed 12s. of me; he never paid me; I was afraid to ask him, for fear be should discharge me. On the 23rd he discharged me; I asked him for the 12s.; he did not pay me, but gave me a note for 10s. I went again, and he wrote me an order for 11s. 6d.

GUILTY Aged 40.—
Confined Four Months.

3031.
JOHN ONIONS,
JAMES ONIONS,
MICHAEL ONIONS,
GEORGE ONIONS , and
JOHN NORTH were indicted for
a misde
meanor.
No evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

3032.
HENRY HYDE was indicted
for assaulting
Theodosia Sarah Williams, with intent, &c.

GUILTY .—
Fined Two Pounds.

3033.
WILLIAM BELL was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of Oc
tober, 2 pairs of pantaloons, value 1l.; I shirt, value 3s.; 2 pairs of drawers, value 4s.; 2 pairs of stockings, value 3s.; 5 printed books, value 2s.; I bag, value 1s. 6d.; 2 waistcoats, value 4s.; 3 shirt-fronts, value 1s. 6d.; and 1 pair of gloves, value 1s.; the goods of
James Dowries, in a certain vessel, in a port of entry and discharge.

JAMES DOWNES . I belong to the ship Jane, which was in the London Docks on the 25th of October—the prisoner had no right to be on board her, but I found him on board that day, with the articles stated, in a bag in his possession—they are mine, and had before been in the forecastle.

Cross-examined by MR. HOLROYD. Q. What time did you leave the ship? A. About one o'clock, and returned about five—I left no one on board—I found the forecastle broken open—I had seen the prisoner along
side the previous evening.
Q. Will you swear tiiat you do not know that he belonged to the Mary? A. No.

.
NOT GUILTY .

3034.
CHARLES WILSON was indicted
for assaulting
Timothy Connor, with intent, &c.

GUILTY . Aged 37—
Confined Nine Months.

p.hi: Fifth Jury, before Edward Bullock, Esq.

div1.p:
3035.
PATRICK M'CORMACK was indicted
for a misdemeanor.
NOT GUILTY .

3036.
JAMES CHATTAN was indicted
for a misdemeanor.
NOT GUILTY .

3037.
PETER JAMES and
WILLIAM JOHNSON were indicted for
a misdemeanor.

HENRY RICHARDSON . I am in partnership with Edward Jenkins—we are slop-sellers, and live in Penny-fields, Poplar. On the 6th of October, about half-past nine o'clock in the evening, I was about closing my shop—the prisoner James was passing the door—I was standing there—he said, "Well, tailor, how do you do?"—I asked him what ship he belonged to—he said he had come from Sheerness with the captain, and that he be
longed to the ship Hartley—he came into my shop—I asked him if he wanted any clothes—he said yes, he did—I took him into a back shop—I asked what he had got a month—he said 3l. 10s., and the other man (meaning Johnson, who was at the door) had only 3l. a month—I asked him if the other man wanted any clothes—he said no, he was too stingy—while we were talking Johnson came in—I was then serving James with clothes—I asked him what he had got to take—he said he was going to be paid next morning in Cheapside, and he appointed to meet me or my young man at the Sailors' Home on the following morning, to go and re
ceive their wages, which the captain had appointed to pay them the follow
ing morning, at Laurie and Hamilton's—James got a pair of pilot trowgen, a waistcoat, and a pilot jacket—Johnson got a jacket and a cap—I let them have them on the supposition that they were going to be paid the next morning, the one 3l. 10s., and the other 3l. per month—we are obliged to let sailors have clothes before they have their money—I ex
pected to be paid the next morning, and I sent my young man to the Sailors' Home—they represented Laurie and Hamilton's to be the owners of the vessel, and that the captain was to meet them there to pay their wages—James said he had 12l. or 13l. to take.

Johnson. Q. Did I come into the shop? A. You came into the back wareroom—you joined with James, and said you had come up with the Hartley from Sheerness with the captain, and on that faith I let you hare the goods.

CHRISTOPHER CULL . I am the prosecutor's servant. I was ordered to go to the Sailors' Home, and on my way I met the prisoners—they had not got the clothes on which they had of my master—they spoke in their own language—I asked if they had been paid—they said, "No"—when they got to our shop they got half-a-crown each from me, which I got from the firm—they then said, if I would go with them to Laurie and Hamilton's they would get their money—I went with them by an omnibus—they said they wished me to go with them to see them get their money, and then they asked me for the half-crown each—I went with them to Laurie and Hamil
ton's—they told me to wait outside, and they would go in and get their money—they went in and came out, but did not bring me any money—I then went into the office by myself—I left the prisoners in Cheapside, and the next morning I went to the Sailors' Home, and could not see them—I went again in the evening, but they were not there—on my way back found the prisoners in the Back road, drinking and carousing—I had my suspicions, and spoke to them—they told me they had not been paid—I waited a good bit, and then they said the second mate had been to tell them they were to be paid at the Sailors' Home.
James. You asked me, on the Monday or Tuesday, if I wanted clothes, and I told you no, only a monkey jacket and trowsers; you made
us drink brandy and gin; I told you I was going to Chcapside to have my prize-money, and you wanted to know if I wanted 10s.

HENRY RICHARDSON
re-examined. When the prisoners were going away, with their clothes tied up, they asked me to give them something to drink, for they were cold, and I told my boy to get a shilling's worth of rum, and give them.

WILLIAM BEDWELL BRADFORD . I am captain of the Hartley. The two prisoners were seamen on board my ship—they had been discharged, and paid their wages, on the 21st of September—they had no wages to receive at Laurie and Hamilton's, or elsewhere.

p.hi:
The prisoner James put in a written defence, stating that he had told the prosecutor that he had received his wages, but had to receive some prize
money at Somerset House, which was true, and after that they had been trusted with the clothes.

div1.p:
JAMES—
GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined Two Months.

JOHNSON—
NOT GUILTY .

3038.
MARY ANN WHITE was indicted
for a misdemeanor.

THOMAS PADDEN . I keep a carpet and general drapery shop in Rat
cliffe-highway. I know the prisoner—Mr. William Blair has been a cus
tomer of mine for eight years—he lives in Red Lion-street, Wapping—the prisoner came to my shop on the 10th of October, about three o'clock in the afternoon—she said, "Mr. Padden, I want seven yards of striped cotton shirting for my master, Mr. Blair"—she said, "My master told me you was to send a bill by me, and he will call in the evening and pay for it: he it gone into the City to get some money"—I let her have it, considering, from what she said, that she came from Mr. Blair—Mr. Blair had some shirts a day or two before—she returned in about half an hour, and said, "Mr. Padden, you have charged my master 1d. a yard too much for the shirt
ing; and have taken 1d. a yard more than you charged him before; but he has sent me for seven yards more, and also for three yards of fine brown holland for my mistress's aprons;" and opening out the bill which I had at first given her, she said, "Master says you must put it all on this same bill; and he will call up and pay you this evening, or at least on Sa
turday morning"—I cut off the shirting and the holland, and she took it a way.

WILLIAM BLAIR . I live at Wapping. The prisoner had been in my service—I dealt with Mr. Padden some time before this occurred—I never sent the prisoner for seven yards of striped cotton, nor for three yards of Holland for my wife's aprons—I never sent her back to say Mr. Padden had charged 1d. a yard too much for it.
FREDERICK JOHN WOOD . I am a pawnbroker. I produce this striped cotton shirting, which I took in pledge of the prisoner—I am certain she is the person.
MR. PADDEN re-examined. These are the same two parcels of striped cotton which I delivered to the prisoner.
Prisoner. I should not have done it, but I got into a woman's company who advised me to do it.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 16.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Four Months.

3039.
SAMUEL THOMPSON was indicted
for assaulting
William Hughes, with intent, &c.
GUILTY . Aged 40.

3040.
SAMUEL THOMPSON was again indicted
for assaulting
George Thaker, with a like intent.

GUILTY . Aged 40.—
Confined Six Months in the Penitentiary.

p.hi: Fifth Jury, before Edward Bullock, Esq.

div1.p:
3041.
JAMES GOSBELL,
EDMUND SMITH , and
FREDERICK SHACKLEFORD were indicted for
a misdemeanor.

DONALD CAMERON . I am in the service of Robert Milbourn, a silk warehouseman, in Newgate-street—he has no partner—on the 16th of May, Shackleford came, and asked whether we served country dealers—I said we did—he said he was commencing business at Maidstone, and wished to open an account at our house, he would pay part in cash, and give respectable references for the balance—he asked to be shown some silks—I showed him some—he selected a parcel, amounting to 81l. 0s. 8d.—he produced this card, and was about writing the names of the referes cm the back of it, when I took him into the counting-house, to the count
ing-house clerk—when he got into the counting-house he wrote these names of the referees—(read)—Bachelard, George-street, Mansion-house; Ingram, Addle-street; and Earp, Fleet-street—on the other side of the card is "Water
loo-house, William Beaumont, Week-street, Maidstone"—Mr. Wells was in the counting-house—I said, "Mr. Beaumont, of Maidstone"—I left the card in the counting-house—Mr. Milbourn was not in at the time—Shackleford left instructions that the goods should be sent at six o'clock, to the Swan
with-two-Necks, Lad-lane—that was all that passed that day—the goods consisted often yards of black satin, sixteen of white satin, and other things—the porter took them that evening—Mr. Wells accompanied him, and received some money—on the next day, the 17th, Shackleford came again, Mr. Milbourn was there then, and sold the goods—he selected number of goods, which came to 77l. 5s. 7d.—he left instructions that they were to be left at the Swan-with-two-Necks, Lad-lane, at six o'clock—he left an order for a box of artificial flowers—on the 23rd be came again, and bought some more goods, amounting to 14l. 16s. and the flowers were sent with them—I addressed him several times as Mr. Beanmont—Mr. Milbourn, in my hearing, addressed him as Mr. Beaumont—he came again on the 31st—he bought some more goods that day, consisting of hand
kerchiefs, shawls, scarfs, crapes, and satinet, in two parcels, which amount
ed to 71l. 13s. 3d., and 14l. 12s. 6d., making 86l. 5s. 9d.—the 14l. 12s. 6d. was to be paid in the middle of the next month—they were to be sent as before, to the Swan-with-two-Necks—there was a direction written on them, "R. W. Beaumont, draper, Maidstone"—on the 6th of July he came again—I sold him ninety-five yards of silk and other goods, amounting to 14l. 12s. 11d.—they were to be paid for on the 1st of August—that par
cel was to be sent to the George Inn, Borough, by his desire, not later

than four o'clock—it was directed to "R. W. Beaumont, draper, Maid
stone"—throughout our dealings we always called him Beaumont, and he answered to that name—if I had believed he was not Beaumont I should not have let him have these goods—the total amount of the goods was 279l., of which we have received 104l., and a few shillings.

Cross-examined by MR. PRICE. Q. Are you one of the persons who gave evidence in a case last Sessions, for obtaining these very goods under false pretences? A, lam—I gave the same testimony—Shakleford was the only person then indicted. (See Eleventh Session, page 1105.)

JOHN WELLS . I am counting-house clerk at Mr. Milbourn's—Cameron introduced Shackleford to me by the name of Beaumont, and gave me this card—there were some references given to me—I remarked they were not trade references, and Shackleford remarked he was sorry he could not give trade references, as he was only now commencing business—among other parties referred to was one of the name of Bachelard—I went to him—I found him in an office at the back of the Mansion House, an office up one pair of stairs, with several clerks in it—it was called the "Cork Stuffing Company"—when I inquired of Bachelard, he said he had known him seve
ral years, he was a highly respectable young man, he knew he had 700l. of his own, and he had lately married a young woman with considerable pro
perty, which could be made available if necessary—that he had houses in Sloane-street, and if he were us he would trust him to any amount—I went from there to Mr. Ingram—he told me he had had the same refer
ences that I had, and he had trusted him to the amount of 150l., and he did not think we should do wrong in trusting him likewise—I then went to Mr. Earp, in Fleet-street—I got a good character of him there, though I did not see Mr. Earp, and on that I permitted the prisoner to have goods—on the evening of the 16th of May I went to the Swan-with-two-Necks with the first parcel of goods, which consisted principally of silks—I asked for Beaumont, and Shackleford appeared—he was in the coffee-room—he paid me 30l. in cash, as agreed when he bought the goods—I went the next evening to the Swan-with-two-Necks again—I saw him again, and he paid me 25l. on account of another parcel of goods left the same evening—I then saw him as Mr. Beaumont—on the 1st of June Shackleford called at the warehouse again, and he then paid me 35l., which was for some goods sold the day before—on the 6th of July I received 14l. 8s. from Shackelford, and he wanted more goods, but Mr. Milbourn refused to let him have them unless he paid for them—there was a bill drawn on him for 122l. 7s., which has been dishonoured—the balance now due to us, is 174l. 16s. 7d.—Freeborn took the goods at all times, and I went with him.
Cross-examined by MR. PRICE. Q, You gave your evidence last time to the same import? A. Yes.

— FREEBORN. I was porter to Mr. Milbourn. On the 26th of May I took some goods to the Swan-with-two-Necks, in company with Mr. Wells—I do not know when was the next time I took any goods there, but I accompanied Mr. Wells, and took the goods he has described, to the Swan-with-two-Necks; and on one occasion I went to the George Inn, in the Borough, with some goods, directed for "Mr. Beau
mont, draper, Maidstone"—I left them at the George.

FREDERICK WINSTONE . I was warehouseman to Mr. Minton, of Cheap
side—he is a wholesale hosier—I remember on the 18th of May seeing

Shackleford at the warehouse, he said he was going to open a shop at Maidstone, and was desirous of opening an account with us—he gave us a card, with "R. W. Beaumont, draper, Maidstone," upon it, and on the back the names of two parties, whom he gave us for reference—Mr. Bachelard, George-street, Mansion-house, and Mr. Ingram, a warehouse
man—he selected some goods, consisting chiefly of hosiery—after he had selected them he left the card, and asked if I would go for the reference, and said he would call again the next day—he said that Bachel
ard knew what money there was in the concern—that was all that passed on that first occasion—on the 19th he called again—he then selected hosiery, consisting of stockings and other things, and fancy goods—the whole amount was considerably above 100l.—he asked if I had been to the reference—I said yes, I had—he took a portion of the goods with him on that day, and the rest were to be sent to Maidstone, by the carrier—we deal in flannel as well as hosiery, but there were no flannels in the parcel he selected that day.

Q. Before this had you been to the referees? A. Yes, on the 18th, after Shackleford called—I went first to Mr. Bachelard—I found him at a house in George-street—I asked him if he knew Mr. Beaumont—he said, yes, he had known him the last ten or twelve years, and more particularly during the last five years—he said Mr. Beaumont had lately married a lady of property, and Mr. Beaumont himself had house property at Chelsea, and 700l, in cash, and he had also a friend who was ready and willing to back him with 1000l, or more—he said he had not the least doubt that he was a strictly honourable and persevering young man, and he had no doubt he would do very well—this was in the Cork Stuffing Office—I told my master, and the goods were sent by Thomas Huddle, our porter, to the Swan-with-two-Necks—on the 20th of May Shackleford called again, and bought some more goods, and on that day he took a por
tion of the goods away with him in a cab, saying he was going over the water, to see the goods properly packed on Larkin's van to Maidstone, and he would save our porter the trouble, that he was going to Maidsfone to get a fresh list of goods that would be necessary to open the shop—the rest of the goods we sent—we saw saw him again afterwards, and he took more goods—I cannot tell what was the whole amount, but the books are here—(referring to them)—the amount of the first parcel, on the 19th of May, which went to the Swan-with-two-Necks, was 11l. 1s. 2d.; on the 20th, 3l. 8s. 6d.—that was the small parcel which he took with him—on the same day, the 20th, we sent goods to the George Inn, Aldermanbury; amounting to 24l. 10s. 1d.—(there are two offices of Larkin's, one in the Borough, and one at the George Inn, Aldermanbury)—on the 21st be bought some more goods, and he said, "I will save you the trouble of sending the goods over the water, I will take them with me in a cab"—there were two pieces of bombazeen and other things bought on that occa
sion, also gloves, stockings, socks, and stocks—the whole amounted to 51l. 13s. 3d.—he said he would bring a fresh list from Maidstone, and we were to see him again on the Monday, which would be the 23rd—on e 23rd he came and bought a small parcel of goods, amounting to 1l. 4s.—he took that away with him in his hand—he came again on the 24th, an bought goods to the amount of 16l. 6s. 9d., which were sent to the George Inn, in the Borough—on the 28th he called again, and bought goods to the amount of 24l. 11s. 3d.—he said he was going to the George Inn, in

the Borough, to see the goods properly packed, and he took them with him in a cab—that was the last parcel, and that was all he had of us—I had never known him by any other name than Beaumont, and all the parcels sent to those various places were addressed, "R. W. Beaumont, Maidstone."

GEORGE FREDERICK MINTON . I am a wholesale hosier and warehouse
man, in Cheapside. On the 18th of May my young man brought a card into my counting-house, with "Beaumont, Maidstone," on it—Shackleford was not there at that time—I desired my young man to make inquiries, and on the following day, in consequence of those inquiries, I permitted the Mr. Beaumont, as I supposed, to have the goods—that was on the 19th, and on the Monday afterwards, which was the 23rd, I went to Mr. Bachelard's, at the Cork Stuffing Company's—Bachelard stated that he had known Mr. Beaumont ten or twelve years, that he was a very respectable young man; he knew he had 900l. capital; he had seen that; and he had married a young lady who had a whole house in Sloane-street, and 300l. a year, and he had a friend who would help him with one or two thousand pounds, or more, if he required it—the communication from Bachelard to me was satisfactory—I believed it to be true, otherwise I should not let Shackleford have the goods—I at last began to have some misgivings—in consequence of that, I desired Shackleford to be shown in to me, and he was so, a few days after the 23rd of May—he then gave himself the name of Ford, and represented himself as buying for Mr. Beaumont—I did not inquire into the state of the account from my young man till early in June—I was not aware it was so heavy till I received a letter from Beaumont, and a further order—I then called on Bachelard again—he offered to be
come surety for 50l. if I would let him have more goods—I considered, and declined it—I went to Maidstone myself about the 21st or 22nd of June—I found the shop, with "Beaumont" over the door—I went into the shop, and saw two persons—one was Mr. Beaumont's father, as I was told, and the other was the prisoner Gosbell—I addressed myself to Gos
bell, in consequence of his coming towards me—I asked him for Mr. Beaumont—he said he was in town, and would not return till Saturday—(this was Thursday)—I then asked for a Mr. Smith—Gosbell said he was gone to Chatham, and would return in the course of that afternoon—I waited in Maidstone the whole of that day, and went to the shop again after ten o'clock at night, when they were closing, in order to see Smith, but I could not, he had not returned—I then asked Gosbell if the buyer was down there—he said no, he never came to Maidstone—I asked him if he knew him—he said he did not, and did not know his name.

Cross-examined by MR. WILDE. Q. Who did you see in the shop besides Gosbell? A. An elderly person—I thought I had seen him before, and I have since ascertained that it was Beaumont, sen.—I saw him afterwards at the Mansion-house, and recognised him as a person who had opened a shop some time before, and wanted to open an account with my house, which I had declined—I think I was at the Mansion-house on the first inquiry, after Shackleford was taken—I do not recollect whether I saw Gosbell the first time—I believe I attended every meeting at the Mansion-house—Gosbell certainly was there the second time, if not the first—he certainly was there on the second occasion—I cannot swear whether he was there on the first—he was no witness that I know of—I do not think he was examined at all—I do not know who he came there with—I saw

him standing, in the body of the Court—he was examined, certainly at one of the meetings—I really do not know whether there was any serive made on him to attend as a witness—I think it was agreed that Mr. God
dard was to write a letter to Mr. Gosbell to come up, but we got no in
formation from him.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. DO you know of any written paper that was sent to Maidstone? A. No—I do not know the fact at all—it was merely a matter of discussion between myself and some other persons—we wanted to possess ourselves of all the information we could, and it was considered desirable to have Gosbell, not as a witness, but in consequence of one of the creditors fancying that Gosbell was only a servant there, he was in
vited to town, as he might give some information—I understood he was to be written to on that account—he came up, and returned to Maidstone, without our being able to elicit any thing from him—subsequently I saw him before the Magistrate—he was put on his defence, and I think he was required to give security for his appearance—he was bound in his own re
cognizance of 40l.—I think that was on the second or third meeting—I think that he was bound to appear—there might have been several meet
ings in which he was not bound over, but I did not notice—I had no con
trol over him—I do not think, after he was put on his defence, that he was discharged, except on his own recognizance—I left this to my attorney to manage—we were desirous of getting what information we could from those whom we believed to be innocently acquainted with the transaction.
Cross-examined by MR. PRICE. Q. Did Shackleford refer you to any other person besides Bachelard? A. Yes, to Ingram—that reference was satisfactory as far as it went—he is a reputable tradesman.
JURY. Q. Did you receive any sum of money? A. Yes, 70l—the balance due to me is 165l. 5s., in the name of Beaumont.

JOHN HUDDLE . I was porter to Mr. Minton—I delivered some goods on the 20th of May at the Swan-with-two-Necks, directed to Mr. Bean
mont, of Maidstone—I took some to the George, Aldermanbury, on the 21st, and some to the George Inn, in the Borough, on the 23rd, and some at other times.

WILLIAM WEST . I am warehouseman to William Thomas and John Smart, silk manufacturers, in Milk-street, Cheapside. On the 2nd of June the prisoner Shackleford called there—I saw him—he handed a card to me with the name of "Robert William Beaumont, Maidstone," saying be wished to make a purchase—he gave references, and said be would call again in two hours—he gave the names of Bachelard, Ingram and Co., and Ridge, Milbourn, and Co, in Newgate-street—he came again, and as some of the parties were out I said he must call again—he said he was quite sure we should be satisfied with the references by making further in
quiries, and he called again in the course of an hour—in consequence of the application to the references by Mr. Smart, we allowed him to open an account on that same day, the 2nd of June—I have the book here—he se
lected that day black silks, satins, and velvets to the amount of 83l. 5s. 5d.—they were to be sent to the Swan-with-two-Necks, Lad-lane, by direction—we sent them addressed to "R. W. Beaumont, Week-street, Maidstone"—they were to be left at the bar of the Swan-with-two-Necks, Lad-lane, and they were done so—the porter took them—I saw Shackle
ford again on the 8th of June—he then had some silk velvets to the amount

of 1l. 4s.—he took them away himself—he came again about a week after the 8th, and looked out a parcel of goods, which I refused to let him have without having the money for them, or part payment for what he had formerly purchased—his answer was, that he would go home, and if they were wanted, he would remit money for them, or let us have part payment for what he had had—there the thing rested—he was given fully to un
derstand that he would have no more goods without part payment—I never saw him again until he was at the Mansion-house—the amount of goods he had was 97l. odd—I did not know him by any other name than Beaumont—I always addressed him by that name.

Cross-examined by MR. PRICE. Q. Is it not common in trade to address a person who is a buyer for a mercantile gentleman, by the name of his employer, when you do not happen to know his name? A. Yes—but I addressed him in the name of the card he gave me—I presumed him to be Mr. Beaumont—the goods were destined for Maidstone, but were to be left at the Swan-with-two-Necks.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. YOU took, him for Beaumont, because he so re
presented himself? A. Yes—the goods were not to be taken to the coach office, but to be delivered at the bar of the Swan-with-two-Necks—whether they got to Maidstone I do not know—we have received no money.

Cross-examined by MR. WILDE. Q. Have you attended to this prosecution? A. Yes—I have not attended any meeting of the creditors—I was present at the'first inquiry before the Magistrates—I think I saw Gosbell there then—I cannot say where he stood—he was passing in and out repeatedly—he was not in any particular part—I did not see him in communication with Mr. Goddard.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. When you were firef before the Magistrate did you know what share Gosbell had been supposed to have taken? A. No.
JENKIN JENKINS . I am porter to Messrs. Smarts'—I delivered the goods at the bar of the Swan-with-two-Necks, for Mr. Beaumont, of Maidstone.

Cross-examined by MR. PRICE. Q. What goods were they? A. Silks and velvets—I carried one parcel—I read the direction on it, "R. W. Beau
mont, Week-street, Maidstone"—I delivered it to the barman.

WILLIAM PATET . I am a perfumer, and live in Lombard-street. On the 25th of May, Shackleford came to my shop—he said be wanted some of our goods, if our prices and terms suited him—I said, "Very well, I dare say they will"—he gave me a card, "B. W. Beaumont, Waterloo
bouse, Maidstone," and on the back he wrote two references, Mr. Bache
lard and a Mr. Yapp, I think, but I did not see him—I went to Mr. Batchelard's, but I saw it was only an office—I did not ring the bell—I returned, and said it was not a business reference, I wanted a business reference—he said, "I can satisfy you on that point," and he gave me two other names, one of which was Mr. Ingram, and said be would call in an hour—I went and saw Mr. Ingram, and the reference to him was such that I went home, and told my shopman to take Mr. Beaumont's order when he came—I supplied him with goods to the amount of 25l. or 26l.;—there was one item of 1l., which he took with him the first day; and the others were sent to Week-street, Maidstone—he ordered a third parcel, but by some good luck we got it back again—the amount of our order, which is unpaid, is 26s. or 27l., I forget which—I have never got any thing for it—I certainly never knew him by any other name than Beaumont.
Cross-examined by MR. PRICE. Q. YOU do not know him by any other

name now, do you? A. No—I gave him this credit on the reference to Mr. Ingram—I never knew Mr. Ingram, before—I did not like Mr. Bache
lard's, because it was an office—our traveller takes a journey twice year, and it was understood that these goods were to be paid for when he called—I did not expect to be paid for them for six months—we executed another small order for him of 7l., which we got back—I did not see him the second time he called.

Cross-examined by MR. WILDE. Q. Did you go before the Magistrate? A. Yes—I have been acting from the first in conducting this prosecution—I was not aware of any meeting of creditors to advise on what should be done, or about having Gosbell up—I was before the Magistrate on the first inquiry—it was in July, I think—I recollect seeing Gosbell on that occasion—I did not speak to him, and I am not aware that he spoke to any person—I cannot tell whether he attended on the second examination by a summons—I know he attended and went away—I cannot remember when he gave his own recognizances, I think it was about the third time—he certainly did not attend as a prisoner.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. DO you know who he came with, or went away with? A. No—I think I heard he was required to be there; and on one occasion he was allowed to go on his own recognizances—I did not know what was to be attributed to Gosbell at that time—I trusted the whole of this to my attorney—from the representation made to me by Shackleford, from beginning to end, I believed him to be Mr. Beaumont, of Waterloo-house, Maidstone.

JAMES LANGLEY . I am porter to Mr. Patey. On the 1st of Jane I took a chest of goods, directed to Mr. Beaumont, Maidstone, to the King's Head, in the Borough—I left them there—I have got the signature for them.

CHARLES WILLIAM WAGSTAFF . I am salesman to Mr. John Mum
ford, of Milk-street, Cheapside, a lace warehouseman. On the 23rd of June, I remember Shackleford coming to my master's warehouse—he asked to look at some goods, which were shown him, and he purchased to the amount of 39l. 9s. 3d.—they consisted of gauze handkerchiefs, blonde, bobbin-net, and other things—he gave his name "Mr. Beaument, Week-street, Maidstone"—he wrote it down himself, and I copied it into the day-book—he wrote down two references, Mr. Ingram, and Mr. Bachelard—of course we inquired of them—I went first to Mr. Ingram—I got there what was satisfactory as to his solvency—I then went to Mr. Bachelard, at the Cork Stuffing Company—Bachelard said that Bean
mont was a very respectable man indeed, and possessed property to the amount of some thousands—we sent the first parcel I believe the same evening, after I had seen the referees—I believe they were sent to the George Inn, in the Borough—that was by his direction—be called again the same evening, between five and seven o'clock, after I had seen the referees—he asked if the parcel was gone—I believe it was not sent then, and he wished it to be sent by some particular hour that evening, as he was going—they were sent, directed to Mr. Beaumont, Week-street, Maidstone—I did not see Shackleford again till the 30th of June, when he called and purchased Lyons nets, fancy nets, Paris nets, and veils to the amount of 15l. 8s. 4d.—he said he should let us have some money the next time he called—I think we sent that second parcel the day after, with the same direction, to the Borough—he called again, I believe, on the

11th or 12th of July, and looked out other goods to the amount of be
tween 20l. and 30l.—while we were looking out these goods my employer, Mr. Mumford, came in, and I introduced Mr. Beaumont, as I supposed him to be, to him, as Mr. Beaumont, of Week-street, Maidstone, and I introduced Mr. Mumford to him, as Mr. Mumford, sen.—Mr. Mumford then asked Shackleford if he was Mr. Beaumont, asked him to give him his Christian name, said he would take it down, and asked whether he had any partner—he said he had not—he asked him if he was buying the goods on his own account—he said he was—he then looked out some goods to the amount of 20l. or 30l.—he was asked by me or Mr. Mumford, where they were to be sent to, but I do not recollect where he said they were to be sent—I do not recollect whether Mr. Mumford wrote down something about that, but I believe he did—I saw him write Beaumont's address—he asked him how the name Beaumont was spelt, and he asked him after he had written it on a paper if he had spelt it right—he said it was quite correct—I did not know Shackleford by any other name than the name he gave.

Cross-examined by Mr. PRICE Q. And you do not know him by any other name now? A. I suppose his name to be Shackleford—I do not think his name is Jenkins, because a plate was found on his person when he was taken, with the name of Shackleford on it, and also some cards—I was examined in Mr. Mumford's case last Sessions against Shackleford, and related the same story—I do not recollect which name was given in first, Ingram or Bachelard—I do not know how I came to go to Mr. Ingram first—I did not know anything of him, or of Mr. Bachelard—Shackleford obtained from us about 55l. worth of goods altogether—the last parcel was not sent.

JOHN MUMFORD . I am warehouseman in Milk-street, Cheapside. On the 11th or 12th of July, I came into the warehouse, and saw Shackleford there, purchasing goods—Wagstaff was the salesman—he introduced Shack
leford to me—he said, "Mr. Mumford, Mr. Beaumont"—tome goods had been arranged to be purchased—I said to Shackleford, "Your name is Beau
mont?"—he said, "It is, my name is Beaumont"—I said, "Are you buying goods on your own account?"—he said he was—he then continued the pur
chase—when he was about to leave, I said, "Where will you have there goods sent to?"—he asked if they could be ready by six o'clock—I laid they could—he said, I wish them to be sent to me at the Railway Tavern"—I then asked him for his name, that it might be entered correctly in the books—I then wrote his name as he dictated—I showed it to him after I had written it, and he said it was right—he said if the goods were sent there at the time, he would pay 15l.—this is the paper I wrote, and showed him—(read)—"Robert William Beaumont, Pool's Railway Tavern, at six o'clock; and send a receipt for 15l."—I directed the goods to be sent—the porter went, and I went with him—when we got to Pool's Railway Tavern I did not find him—I ordered the goods to be taken home—I afterwards took him in a tobacconist's shop, in Fenchurch-street—he was about making a purchase of cigars.

Cross-examined by MR. PRICE Q. Have you given us the same ac
count as you did last Sessions? A. Yes—I believe he did not pay for the cigars—I have no means of knowing his name, but by what he gave—I have seen it written.
Cross-examined by MR. WILDE Q. Were you present at any meeting of the creditors? A. I think I was—we had many conferences from the

26th of July to the 1st of August—Mr. Mintonand others were there—I do not remember whether it was at Mr. Goddard's office—Gosbell was there and was asked many questions—I cannot recollect any instructions given to Mr. Goddard to send to Maidstone—I accompanied Roe to Maidstone, and saw Gosbell there—he gave me some information—I do not recollect his offering to have his house searched—I remember Gosbell being ex
amined, but I cannot tell when—I think Kimbrell was examined on the first inquiry—I do not know whether Gosbell was bound over before or after Kimbrell's evidence—I cannot recollect—there was a meeting of the credi
tors on the case of Shackleford at Mr. Goddard's office—Kirobrell was not present then—Gosbell was there, as a person assisting the prosecution—he from time to time gave information relative to it, and in consequence of that not proving satisfactory, he was prosecuted.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. You took Shackleford, and at first the proceed
ings were against him? A. Yes; and from time to time other informa
tion came out—Gosbell was examined at Mr. Goddard's office, and after
wards Kimbrell was sent for and examined.
GEORGE HERTSELL . I am porter to Mr. Mumford. On the 23rd of June I took a parcel to the George, in the Borough, addressed to Mr. Beaumont, of Maid-stone—I left it there.

HENRY WILLIAM INGRAM . I am a woollen warehouseman in Addle-street. On the 13th of May Shackleford came to my warehouse—he pre
sented a card with a reference to Mr. Bachelard, in George-street, Man
sion-house; "R. W. Beaumont, of Week-street, Maidstone," was on the card—he said he wished to purchase goods of me—he said he was about opening a shop at Maidstone—he said the shop was taken, and he wanted some goods—I did not see him write the name of the referee—I promised to go to Bachelard—I went there that day—I saw him, and he said he knew Beaumont, that he had about 600l. or 800l. in the business, and his wife had some property in houses in Sloane-street—I was satisfied of the solvency of Beaumont, from the account be gave me—Shackleford looked out goods that day, part woollen goods, and part trowsers—they amounted to 50l. 5s.—they were sent to the Swan-with-two-Necks, by his direction—my porter, James Steel, took them—I will not say how they were ad
dressed—on the day after, there was another parcel to the amount of 56l. 14s. 6d.—he paid my salesman 20l. on the 13th, and in all he paid 80l.—106l. 3s. 6d. is the balance remaining due—the witness came to me from Mumford's and Patey's for a reference—I was induced to give a satisfactory account of Beaumont, by having a reference myself, and being paid part of my account.

Cross-examined by MR. PRICE. Q. You had no intention of assisting the person who applied to you, to obtain these goods? A. Not in the least—I gave the character which I thought he had, honestly and fairly—others may have done the same thing—I gave my opinion, and thought they might do as they liked—I was examined last sessions on Shackleford's trial.
MR. DOANE Q. Did you believe all through that Shackleford, whom you believed was Beaumont, was a respectable man? A. Yes.

GEORGE MILLS . I am in Mr. Ingram's employ—I went down to Maid
stone in May, about three weeks after the account was opened—I found a shop there, partly fitted up—I saw Gosbell there—I told him I came from Mr. In
gram's—I asked to see Mr. Beaumont—Gosbell said Mr. Beaumont had left that morning for town, and most likely he would call on Mr. Ingram—I asked

him his opinion of Mr. Beaumont's respectability—he laid he believed Mr. Beaumont to be a very respectable man, having married a lady of considerable property, that, if he had any property, and Mr. Beaumont wished for a partner, he should have no objection to place his money at Mr. Beaumont's disposal for business, he would be very happy to join him in business—I thought there was a deficiency in the shop, and I stated there must have been a great quantity of goods bought in London to my knowledge, and I wanted to know where they were—there was not sufficient in the shop to satisfy me—he said they did not receive the goods in the shop entrance, but at the side door, and immediately passed them into the cellar—I did not go into the cellar.

Cross-examined by MR. WILDE. Q. You asked Gosbell what he was? A. Yes; he said he was a man employed by Mr. Beaumont—I asked if he was the managing man—he said there was a Mr. Smith there, bat he was out, or had left for London, or something to that effect—Mr. Beau
mont's name was over the shop-door—I had heard, before I went down, that there was such a shop at Maidstone, and I wrote there to ascertain the fact—when I returned I went to Bachelard's—what Gosbell had stated was carried out by what Bachelard stated, and I sent more goods—I had a conversation with one creditor, who said that the parties were respectable.
MR. DOANE. Q. Who was that creditor? A. Mr. Minton—I sent more goods to Beaumont, after what Gosbell had told me about his marrying this lady.

Cross-examined by MR. PRICE. Q. Did you not know that Beaumont was only commencing business? A. Yes; but I knew what he repre
sented, and how many goods he had bought, and I knew that goods ought to be in the shop if he intended to open business—I first went to Maid
stone by Mr. In gram's direction; and again, in a fortnight, of my own ac
cord—Gosbell appeared to be shopman—I do not know that Beaumont has married a person of property—I did not know Bachelard till I called on him—I called on him several times, and I met him in the street—Gosbell answered me candidly and fairly, as far as I could judge, some questions, and some he did not—be told me that the person in the shop, who I knew to be old Mr. Beaumont, was another name—I only knew about Mr. Beaumont from what I heard.
JAMES STEEL . I am porter to Mr. Ingram. I took some goods for Mr. Beaumont, of Maidstone, to the Swan-with-two-Necks, on the 13th of May—I left them there.

WILLIAM KIMBRELL . I was pot-boy, at the Bull and Mouth tap in July—I lived there six months—I left in the summer, to go to the Geeat Western Railway—I have been there about three months—while I was at the Bull and Mouth, Shackleford used to come there—he used to go by the name of Mr. Shackleford—Smith and Gosbell used to come there, and also a person who went by the name of Beaumont—they used to come very often—they frequented the parlour together—sometimes they came one or two together, and sometimes they came separately, and then inquired for the others—we had brown paper parcels brought to the house by porters—I saw one of the porters here just now—some parcels I have had to take care of for the prisoners—Smith and Beaumont have given them me to take down stairs—Gosbell and Shackleford have been there at the time, and five or six persons in the room—I have seen Smith open some parcels—they contained silk handkerchiefs, and scarfs with

knots tied in the fringe, crape shawls, coarse shawls, and silk velvets—I have seen them move them about on the tables, and then tie them up again—I have seen Smith pull out a coarse bag with a great deal of money in it, and put it on the table, and they were receiving some—what he gave them I cannot say—I have seen Shackleford there at the time, and another short gentleman, when I have seen Smith counting out the money to them, while they stood round a table, and a pen and ink and some paper I brought in—the goods were then taken away—I took one parcel for Smith, and put it in the buss, and he gave me sixpence—sometimes the goods have been put into cabs—Smith, Shackleford, Gosbell, and a short gentleman, have been present when the goods have been taken out of the room—I do not know any public-house in Barbican, but Smith has told me if any one called to see Mr. Beaumont to say he was gone to Barbican—I have had bits of paper from him to tell that, and if any one came, and inquired for Mr. Smith, or Mr. Shackleford, I have given them the pieces of paper—they were in the habit of coming to the honse very nearly all the time I lived there—my mistress was not satisfied with one or two things, and she forbid them all the house—I heard her forbid Shackleford the house, and would not serve him.

Cross-examined by MR. PRICE Q. Perhaps he could not pay hit bills? A. He always paid very well—there was no waiter but me—there was a female servant—she has served Mr. Shackleford with half-a-pint of wine, when he has been up stairs with his lady, and I perhaps was out of the way at the time, cleaning the pots—I do not know her name—she did not wait on company, only when I was busy—I have had nothing given me for coming here—I should not have come if I had not been made to come—I am now engaged at the Great Western Railway, looking after some horses for Mr. Saunderson—I lived with my father at Buckingham five years ago, and helped him in the stables—I then went to live with an aunt at Baltown—I have lived with Mr. Chantry, at Colchester—I misbehaved myself, and he dismissed me—I then went to Mr. Saunder
son, who sent me to the Bull and Mouth tap—I was there six months—I cannot say when these gentlemen first began coming backwards and for
wards—many strangers used to come—I cannot tell the first or last day I saw either of the prisoners—they came frequently before I, left—I can
not say how often—I took no more notice of them than of other cus
tomers—I noticed the parcels—other persons took notice of these things as well as I did—a mail guard did, and Mr. Smith pulled off his coat to fight him—the guard came and told my mistress that she ought not to encourage them there, they were a pack of swindlers, and nothing else—Mrs. Saunderson was my mistress—she is not here—she did not attend on the gentlemen in the parlour, that was my business—it was at the bar that she forbade Mr. Shackleford the house—they never went into any room but the coffee-room—Mrs. Saunderson might take a thing in now and then—perhaps I have been in seven or eight times, in the course of the day, answering the bell—Mr. Shackleford never used to go and sit in the bar—mistress did not like him well enough—she did not approve of him, nor of any of them, so she said—I never saw any customers sit down in the bar—there is a bar maid—she may have gone into the coffee-room if I was out of the way—I heard my mistress tell Mr. Shackleford that she did not wish him to come there "at all, and she has said to me that she wished they would go somewhere else, and have their things—it was

Mr. Smith that showed me the handkerchiefs—he opened them—I do not know whether it was for the express purpose of showing them to me—there were five or six parcels opened at the same time on the table—he did not say why he showed them to me—he said they were beauties—he opened them, and pulled them one off the other—I took something into the room at the time—I was against the table, looking at them—I was not called to look at them—they were tied up again, and taken away.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE Q. When did you first hear that you would be wanted as a witness against these parties? A. I heard nothing about it till a man came after roe at the Great Western Railway—I do not at all recollect when it was, but he said I must come to the Man
sion-house, at eleven o'clock next morning, to give evidence—it was more than a month after I left the Bull and Mouth—I should not think it was two months—the man brought me a paper—when the Lord Mayor asked me if I knew the prisoner, I said yes—no one had spoken to me before that—I cannot tell how long after I had been at the Bull and Mouth I first saw either of the three prisoners, or which I first saw—I did not know there were two Mr. Smiths—there was Mr. Beaumont, a stout gen
tleman—I cannot say how many times I have seen Mr. Smith bring paper parcels there, but very frequently—I have seen him bring them in and take them away under his arm—I cannot say when I first saw him bring any parcels—I saw two others, besides Mr. Smith, bring parcels—one was a man with a wen on his cheek—I do not recollect a man named Ketcher—I cannot tell when it was that I carried the parcel for Mr. Smith, for which he gave me 6d.—I cannot say how long it was before I left—I do not know that I should know the handkerchiefs again which Mr. Smith showed me—some were bright yellow ones—(looking at some produced by Mr. Ballantine)—I could not swear to these—I will not say either way——(looking at some others)—I cannot swear to these—they may be brought out of the shop like them, and then I should not know—(looking at others)—these are like the handkerchiefs I saw, but they may not be them—Mr. Smith opened the yellow ones to show me—I took particu
lar notice of them—I do not know a person named Bates, who was in the habit of coming to the house—I cannot say whether any parcels were brought on the 9th of July, or on the 11th, 12th, or 13th—I took no notice of the time, nor can I say when these handkerchiefs were shown to me—my mistress might have been very good friends with Mr. Smith—I saw none of it—he was a very good customer, for aught I know, he always paid for what he had—she did not like any of them, and did not study their custom—I cannot recollect that she mentioned any names when she said she did not like any of them.

Cross-examined by MR. WILDE Q. I suppose you went out on errands from time to time? A. If mistress wanted me to go—I was discharged from my service at Colchester for stopping out till eleven o'clock, or half-past, when I ought to have been home at ten; and also I met with two or three accidents, I broke a pony's knees—there are plenty of ostlers in the yard, at the Bull and Mouth, employed to look after the coaches and busses—the prisoners used to go into the coffee-room—Mr. Shackelford had a private room, and used to go up stairs with a young woman—Gosbell used to go into the coffee-room—that is a public room—I cannot tell when it was I have seen him there—I do not know what month it was in—he used to be there frequently along with Shackelford, Smith, and

Beaumont—he came along with the rest, at the same time as they came—I cannot say whether it was in January, February, March, or when it was—I never kept any account of when he was there, when he came, or when he went away—I have seen him there along with the rest—I have seen other people come with these parties from time to time—other persons used the house—I cannot say that I have not had luggage to take care of for a gentleman, but I had plenty of parcels for these gentlemen.

MR. DOANE. Q. Was it just before you left the Bull and Mouth that you saw these people, and the others you have named, frequenting the house? A. It was not long before—they used to come there three or four times a day sometimes—I saw them till I did leave—Mr. Sherman is the owner of the Bull and Mouth—Mr. Saunderson is his son-in-law—I am in the same service now.

WILLIAM SWANSON . I am porter at the Swan-with-two-Necks. I have seen Shackleford there—I first saw him there towards the end of May last—he asked if I had any parcels for Mr. Beaumont, of Maidstone—I said I had one, it was a box—I gave him the parcel, directed to Mr. Beaumont, of Maidstone—he left it in my care again, and went into the coffee-room—he came again the same day, and took it away in a cab—a great many more parcels came directed to Mr. Beaumont, of Maidstone—I saw Shackleford daily for a fortnight or three weeks after—the parcels were sometimes boxes, and sometimes brown paper parcels, sometimes small trusses—they were always taken away by Shackleford, with the exception of three, which were carried away by a porter—Shackleford was there when the porter came for the first, and of course he had the others by Shackleford's directions—one or two letters came directed to Mr. Beaumont, which were left at the bar—they were given to Shackle
ford—I saw him open one or two—be generally took parcels away in the cab—I addressed him as Mr. Beaumont, and he always answered to that name—there is a gateway going into Lad-lane—I always fetched the cabs for Shackleford, with the exception of one or two—the cab was driven up the gateway into the yard to the door of the hotel, the goods were put in, and Shackleford drove off—people passing could not see what was going on up the gateway, unless they stopped to look up the yard—I saw him there for a fortnight or three weeks, sometimes once a day, sometimes twice a day—he always came to fetch parcels for Beaumont, of Maidstone. Cross-examined by MR. PRICE Q. You saw no others there taking any part in this? A. No; there were others—I do not know that Shackle
ford's name is not Beaumont—when a man has luggage to take away, the cabs generally stop in the street—if we fetch a cab for a gentleman, we leave it outside—all this was done under Shackleford's direction.

MR. DOANE Q. There were others with him? A. I saw one or two in company with him, but that was generally in the coffee-room—I never spoke to them—I have seen him in company with the same persons more than once—the parcels were not sent to Maidstone, because Shackleford called and desired all parcels directed to Beaumont, of Maidstone, to be taken care of.

THOMAS HARRIS . I am a grocer, and live at Maidstone—I know Shackle
ford. In the beginning of last June I was engaged as porter by a man named Beaumont, who is not in custody, to attend to a draper's shop in Week-street Maidstone—it was opened the day I went, which I believe was on Saturday,
