the 11th of June—there were two Beaumonts, the father and son—I saw them both, and Mr. Gosbell and a Mr. Smith, but not this prisoner—they all appeared to act as shopmen and masters—it was some time before I knew who was master—Gosbell was assisting in the shop as shopman—the stock of the shop appeared to consist but of few goods—I remained there till the shop was closed, which was some time about the middle of August—I only know of two parcels coming down during that time—I did not see any silks or velvets in the shop—there were four shawls hanging up, I did not see any more—customers came and asked for articles they could not be supplied with, and went away without being served—Beaumont and Smith were there till the Wednesday in the first week—they then left, and came back again on Saturday evening—they went away again, I suppose on the Monday, and returned on the following Saturday, about six o'clock in the evening, with two ladies—Shackleford came with them—I shut up the shop that night between eleven and twelve o'clock, and I went home—I asked Gosbell what time I should come on Monday morning to open shop—he went into the room behind the shop, where Smith, the two Beaumonts, and Shackleford were, to inquire—he came back, and said I was not wanted till eight o'clock—I went on the Monday morning about eight—the shop was open—Gosbell was there, and the elder Beaumont—I did not see any others—Beaumont told me to dust the window, and then he said I was not wanted, I might look in about noon—I left the shop—I returned between twelve and one o'clock, and found the elder Beaumont there—on the following Saturday young Beau
mont and Smith came down in the last buss, about half-past nine in the evening—they staid about half-an-hour, and then wept away—I have not seen them since—Gosbell and old Beaumont continued at the shop—old Beaumont re
mained there till the shop was closed, which was in the middle of August, on a Thursday—I closed the shop on the Wednesday night—Beaumont desired me to get a cart to remove the goods, and said he should not open the shop any more—I got a cart the following morning to remove the remainder of the stock, and what furniture there was, to a house which his wife had taken opposite the barracks—I went there with a cart and donkey at five o'clock—I found old Beaumont there—he directed me, and I took the things to this house opposite the barracks—there was some hosiery and other linen
drapery goods, there were six boxes in all—there was very little furniture, I suppose altogether it was not worth 50l.—after Smith and Beaumont had left the last time, I saw a decrease in the quantity of stock, from the shelves—some pieces that hung about the shop for making dresses were gone—young Beaumont's wife was there for three or four days—no goods were unpacked in the cellar while I was there—I went into the cellar several times, I never saw any goods there—I had to go there every evening, to turn the gas on and off.

Cross-examined by MR. PRICE Q. Have there not been some injurious reports about the Beaumonts? A. There had been; two gentleman came down one morning, and were talking there for three quarters of an hour—Beaumont left Maidstone before I heard any rumours—the goods were removed openly in an uncovered cart, and we were there till ten o'clock.

Cross-examined by MR. WILDE Q. What was your occupation when you first went there? A. The first thing I did was to clean the windows—I attended there every day, and went round with some bills all round the town—I had to go out with goods when any went out—they used to tell

me every evening whether they wanted me, then I did what was wanted, and looked in again—I knew nothing of them previous to the 11th of June—there were four or five mats in the cellar which had had furniture packed in them—I did not see matting round the furniture—I was the only servant in the house—I was cook—there was a woman there on the first Saturday—I set up grocer again as soon as I could get a situation—I am not a grocer on my own account—Gosbell did not continue in the house so long as Mr. Beaumont—Goshell did not leave directly after Mr. Mum
ford came down—I do not recollect his leaving till one Friday afternoon, which must have been the latter end of July.

MR. DOANE Q. What were the rumours about this shop? A. I heard they had been obtaining goods under false pretences, which I be
lieve was current in the newspapers—there was no regular female servant—the whole of the house was not furnished, only the sitting-room at the back of the shop, and two rooms up stairs—each had a bed in them—there was no servant beside me—I was there day by day, from the 11th of June till the Wednesday in August when the shop was closed—I was paid in the evening for the day.

Cross-examined by MR. WILDE Q. Do you remember when Gosbell came? A. No, I found him there on the Saturday I went there—he was there but very little the last three weeks—I think he was there the night before the shop closed.

WILLIAM MORRIS (City police-constable.) I found Shackleford in custody of Mr. Mumford, in a tobacconist's in Fenchurch-street—I took him to the station, and found on him a plate and some cards engraved, which are "F. Shackleford, wine and spirit-merchant, Brighton, Dealer in cigars of the first quality"—I have looked after Charles Sidney Smith, Bachelard, and the two Beaumonts, without success.

JAMES BRANNAN (police-sergeant G 20.) I have had a warrant against Charles Sidney Smith, Bachelard, and the two Beaumonts, and have looked diligently for them, in company with inspector Shackle night after night.
JOSEPH SHACKLE . I am a police-inspector. I have searched with Brannan, and in vain.
JURY to WILLIAM KIMBRELL. Q. You saw some parcel opened; did you see whether it was directed at all? A. No, I saw some were directed, but I did not see this one.
(William Green, a linen draper, of Church-street, Hackney, gave Gosbell a good character.)

GOSBELL—
GUILTY . Aged 29.

SMITH—
GUILTY. Aged 45.
Judgment Respited.

SHACKLEFORD—
GUILTY . Aged 36.

3042.
EDWARD BAKER was indicted
for feloniously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
James Roberts, on the 14th of October, at
West Ham, and stealing therein, 1 basket, value 1s.; 25 spoons, value 7l.; 16 forks, value 8l.; and one fish-slice, value 15s., his goods; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

CAROLINE REYNOLDS . I am servant to Mr. James Roberts, of Upton
place,

West Ham. On the afternoon of the 14th of October, on going into the parlour, I noticed the shadow of a figure on the side-board—I was alone in the house—I looked through the door, and saw the prisoner standing against the dining-room table, in the middle of the room, with the plate-basket in his hand—on seeing me, he turned round, looked at me, and jumped out of the window, taking the plate-basket with him—I followed, and seized hold of him as he was getting over the gate leading into the back garden—I got possession of the plate-basket—I do not recollect whether he relinquished his hold, or whether I took it from his hand, but all in a moment I found the basket in my possession—I laid hold of his coat after I got the basket, and called out "Murder" and "Police"—I felt him, as I thought, shifting to get his coat off—I then let go my hold of the skirts of his coat, took up the plate-basket, went into the back garden, and gave an alarm—he was brought back in about three-quarters of an hour or an hour—I am sure he is the same man—he left his hat behind him, and in it were several religious and other tracts, and a sheet almanack—a coat was also brought to me, which was such a one as he had when I caught hold of him—the plate-basket had been on the side-board before I saw the prisoner with it—the window was at that time shut down—I found it open when I saw him standing in the parlour—the door of the house was shut—there was no other way of getting in except through the window—I do not know how he would get to the parlour window without getting over the wall and the iron palisades—the plate-basket contained the articles stated, which are worth upwards of 20l.—it is my master's property—I gave information to a man named Miller, who went in pursuit—he is too unwell to be here.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE Q. You were very much alarmed when you saw the prisoner? A. Yes—I had an opportunity of seeing his face while I was struggling with him, and I saw him through the crack of the door before I went into the parlour—I knew him again directly I saw him.

JOHN WILCOX (police-constable K 368.) On the afternoon of the 14th of October, I was crossing the fields towards Upton, and saw the prisoner jump over the fence of Mr. Gurney's park, which is, I should say, about three-quarters of a mile from the prosecutors premises—a great number of people were pursuing him—a conductor of the Parcel's Delivery Company stopped him in the park—I took hold of him, and asked why he ran—he said, because other people ran—he was the first man—a person named Miller came up when I got him to the station—in consequence of what he said, I took him to the prosecutor's house, and Reynolds said he was the man that took the plate-basket out of the parlour—he said, "Women must say something; I suppose I must hear it"—this hat was found in the garden, containing tracts and other things, such as people hawk about, and the coat was found in the next house—the prisoner denied that either were his—he put them on at Lambeth-street—he had no hat or coat on when I stopped him.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you help him on with them at Lambeth police-ofiice? A. No—one of the officers did.

MARIA THING . I am the wife of Mr. Robert's groom. I heard some
body call out, and ran up the garden—I saw the prisoner come quickly out of the water-closet—he nearly pushed me down—his hat came off, and he shifted one arm off his coat—he went over the wall, and got away into the next garden.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

ROBERT SUTTLF .(police-constable B97.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—I was present at his trial, and know him to he the person described in this certi
ficate—(read.)

GUILTY .* Aged 29.—
Transported for Fifteen Years.

3043.
ALICE WALKER and
ELIZA SMITH were indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of October, 70lbs. weight of coals, value 1s., the goods of
William Fredcrick Brown.
WILLIAM FREDERICK BROWN . I had two tons of coals in a gravel hole at the Eastern Counties Railway—I am the contractor—these coals produced resemble mine in every respect.

JOHN PHILPOT . At half-past six o'clock in the morning of the 14th of October I was in my field at Barking—I saw the two prisoners coming from Mr. Brown's place, carrying something heavy across the fields—I followed—they each had a bag—I went to Smith's house, and asked what they had in their bngs—they said only a few cinders which they had picked up on the railway—I found they had about 70lbs. Of coals, which exactly resembled Mr. Brown's.
Walker's Defence. I saw these bits of coals lying on a piece of waste ground, and next morning we went and picked them up.
Smith's Defence. These were pieces that had dropped about; we took them from where there was no person's property.

WALKER—
GUILTY . Aged 52.

SMITH—
GUILTY . Aged 27.
Confined Two Months.

3044.
HARRIET PRUE was indicted
for stealing, on the 13th of September, at
St. Nicholas, Deptford, 1 pair of sugar tongs, value 12s.; I rings, value 1l.; 2 sheets, value 1l.; 1 coat, value 3l.; 1 pair of trowsers, value 1l.; 1 waistcoat, value 10s.; 3 gowns, value 1l. 14s.; 1 cloak, value 1l. 10s.; 3 handkerchiefs, value 6s.; 1 veil, value 4s.; and 2 shawls, value 1l. 15s.; the goods of
Charles Skeet, in his dwelling-house.

ELIZABETH SKEET . I am the wife of Charles Skeet, and live at No. 7, Broomfield-row, St. Nicholas, Deptford—my husband rents the whole house. The prisoner came to lodge at our house at the latter end of July, as near as I can say—she said she was the wife of Hodges, a policeman, who came to live there with her—I thought they were man and wife—mj husband is a ship-keeper, and in the habit of going from home—I used to go to him on Sunday to spend the day, and the prisoner and Hodges were left in the house—I had noticed the prisoner many times leave the house with a basket and bundle when Hodges was at home—I have asked her at different times what she was taking away—she said she was going to the tailor's to get the police clothes altered—I asked her if she was going again—she said, "Yes," for they were very uncomfortable—the last time she left the house she borrowed a basket of me, and said she should be back on Tuesday to tea, but she did not return—I did not see her

again till she was in custody—I went to my drawers, and missed the sugar tongs, also some rings, my husband's clothes, my mother's large cloak, a silk shawl and veil, a pair of sheets, two pillow-cases, two gowns of ray mother's, a silk dress of my own, and other articles, worth together 10l. or 15l.—they may have been taken in less quantities than 5l. value at a time—my husband's clothes were safe on the Sunday before she left, the cloak was in the same chest; and on the Tuesday, when I went to them, I found they were gone—the prisoner was then gone—when she came to my house she had nothing but a very small parcel in her hand—she said her trunk was coming, but it never came.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Was Hodges living with her up to the last? A. Yes, up to the very last day of her going away—she left on Tuesday the 13th, and he came back on the Wednesday morning—ours is a four-roomed house.

MARY ASWELL . I have seen the prisoner leave the house with bundles from time to time—on the 12th of September I saw her go out with a large and small bundle, and after that I heard her say to a woman opposite where I live, that she was going away the next day.

JAMES WAINSCOT . I am a policeman of Hereford. On Sunday even
ing, the 18th of September, I apprehended the prisoner at her mother's house at Hereford—I told her I was going to take her to the station, on a charge of felony, for robbing her lodging—she said she knew nothing of it—I asked her where her box was—she said it had been by Cook's ran, and was left on the road—on the Tuesday morning I received the box out of the van, and took it to the station—the superintendent cautioned her not to answer, and asked her if the box was hers—she said it was—I found this silk dress and crape shawl in it—I asked if it was hers—she said yes, she had bought it for 10s., of one John Elgar, who was in the habit of coming to Skeet's house, and who said it belonged to his wife, who was dead.
Cross-examined. Q. I believe you found the box at Cirencester? A., Yes, in consequence of what she said—it was opened in her pretence.

HENRY DIMOND . I am a policeman. I was sent into the country to apprehend the prisoner—she told me the silk dress she bought of Elgar and she was to give 10s. for it—that the had given him 3s. and was to give him the rest afterwards.

JOHN ELGAR . I am a seaman, and live in Tooley-street—I never sold the prisoner anything—I take my meals at Skeet's—I was only there once since the things were lost—I had my meals down stairs, in the front room—Mrs. Skeet was there at the time.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you know the prisoner? A. Only from seeing her there—I had my breakfast, dinner, and tea there—I never slept there—I never sold the prisoner anything whatever—I am positive I did not sell her this silk dress.

COURT Q. Do you know Hodges, who passed as her husband? A. Yes—I have seen him there—he was dressed as a policeman—I never sold her a gown—I never sold her any thing—she never gave me any money, and I never gave her any clothes.

MR. DOANE Q. Have you not, on one or more occasions, called at Skeet's on a Sunday? A. Not since the things were stolen—I cannot say, exactly, what time it was—I have been to the door, but not in the house—I did not owe a public-house score on the Sunday night I called—I swear that I did not say so—I had been in the habit of calling or going by the

house for several Sundays before, but not of going in—I never went into the house on a Sunday night after I left Mrs. Skeet's—I cannot tell when I ceased to board there—I only went to the door to pass the compliment of the day with the prisoner—I was acquainted with a great many more in that row—I swear that I never sold any thing to the prisoner on a Sunday I did not sell her the gown and scarf, and tell her not to say anything to "mother" about it as I owed a score at a public-house—I used to call Mrs. Skeet mother—I did not sell the things to the prisoner for 10s. and receive 3s.

COURT Q. Did you go there on a Sunday, before you ceased to board at Skeet's? A. Yes—I used to call at the door in general—Mrs. Skeet was not on shore till the evening—I used to come ashore with her and walk up to the house with her.

ELIZABETH SKEET
re-examined. Elgar took his meals at my house—the property was in my bed-room—he was not there, to my knowledge, after the Sunday before the prisoner left, but I was with my husband on the Sunday on board a ship—I never noticed any intimacy between the prisoner and Elgar—Hodges is here—no other seaman but Elgar was in the house—I have traced no more of the property—I do not know what has become of the basket I lent her—she had her own basket, my basket, and a bundle, when she went out on Tuesday—she said she should return to tea, and asked me to keep the tea-kettle by the fire until seven o'clock, when she should come—Hodges was there on Monday and Tuesday—the prisoner always paid for the lodging.

MR. DOANE Q. Had not she given you reason to believe that she was going to return to her mother in the country? A. Yes—as she said Hodges was going into business again—she said she was going on the Wednesday, but she went on Tuesday—she said she expected a post-office order from her mother—she said if the order was there, waiting for her, she should return that night, about seven o'clock, and if not, I was to wait till next morning—Hodges said he was to meet her at Westminster-bridge at ten, if she did not return at seven—I heard nothing about her having to go to Mr. Smith's, in Whitecross-street, or that her fare was to be paid at the office at Hereford—she said she was going to stop there four or five days—Elgar owes me 2s. 7d. for trifling things—he told me that he had been to my house on a Sunday, but I did not see him—he bad his victuals with us on Sundays on board a ship—he sometimes went on shore, and I have heard that he has called at our house—the prisoner said so—I asked how long he stopped—she said "Oh, he did not stay above a quarter of an hour, he was rather in liquor."

COURT. Q. Where did you lose your two sheets from? A. From the linen-chest in the room I occupied—all the things I lost were from my room—Hodges was a policeman of the R division, and acted as such until the last day, (Tuesday)—he was taken up on this charge, and let out on bail, I believe—he gave up his police situation on that Tuesday, and gave up his clothes the very day she left—Hodges was at home and in bed at times, when the prisoner carried out bundles, as he was on night duty—my mother's things were in the same box—I had told the prisoner I did not go to that box, as I could not bear to look at the things, having recently lost my mother—Elgar did not know where I kept them—he was never up stairs to my knowledge.

JAMES WAINSCOT
re-examined. I have known the prisoner five or six years, and knew her mother—she always bore a good character at He
reford—she left there six or eight months ago, I do not know why—I

have known Hodges all his life, he is a Hereford man—he was not a po
liceman at Hereford—he assisted the prisoner's husband in business, who is a butcher—Hodges left Hereford about the same time as the prisoner—his wife goes out washing—Cirencester is forty or fifty miles from Here
ford—I searched the prisoner's mother's house before I got the box—she told me she had bought them of Elgar, and told me the name of the ship he might be found at.

HENRY DIMOND
re-examined. Hodges resigned from the R division of police on account of getting something better to do—he gave up of his own accord—he had been about five months in the force.

GUILTY of stealing under 5l. Aged 21.—Recommended to mercy by the prosecutrix. —
Transported for Seven Years.

3045.
SARAH POCOCK was indicted
for stealing, on the 22nd of October, 1 rug, value 2s.; the goods of
Frederick Holt.

FREDERICK HOLT . I am a bootmaker, and live at Woolwich. On Monday, the 17th of October, the prisoner came to lodge at my house, and was there three weeks—a week ago yesterday I missed a rug, which was let with the room—this now produced is it.

JOHN BARR . I am shopman to Mr. Moore, a pawnbroker, at Wool
wich—this rug was pawned by a female—I do not know who—this is the duplicate I gave to the person.

MICHAEL BROWNE . I am a policeman. I was on duty at the station at Woolwich, last Thursday evening—the prisoner came and asked to see a man named Pocock, who was there charged with stealing this rug—I asked what she wanted—she said "To liberate Pocock, because he is in
nocent, and I am guilty; I have taken the rug;" and she handed me this duplicate.
Prisoner's Defence. I pledged the rug, but intended to redeem it.

GUILTY. Aged 31.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Fourteen Days.

3046.
MARIA TRAPP and
MARY PORTER were indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of October, 21bs. weight of bread, value 4d., the goods of
John Baker; to which

TRAPP pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 21.

PORTER pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 19.

3047.
JAMES M'CARTHY was indicted
for stealing, on the 12th of October, 5 shillings, 9 sixpences, and 1 groat, the monies of
Thomas Phillips; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .*—
Transported for Seven Years.—Convict Ship.

3048.
THOMAS BARTHOLOMEW was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of October, 1 box, value la.; 1 hat, value 10s.; 1 pair of boots, value 10s.; 1 pair of socks, value 6d.; 1 shirt, value 2s.; and 1 stock, value 4s.; the goods of
John Cain; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Six Months.

3049.
THOMAS BROWNE was indicted
for stealing, on the 8th of October, 8 1/2 lbs. weight of soap, value 5s. 4d., the goods of
Charles Mayer Talmage; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 34.—
Confined Six Months.

3050.
JOHN WALLACE was indicted
for stealing, on the 22nd of October, 1 pewter pot, value 1s., the goods of
Henry Edwin Jaegers.

ALEXANDER M'NOUGHER . I am in the service of Henry Edwin Jag
gers, who keeps the Artillery Canteen at Woolwich. On the 22nd of Oc
tober I heard a noise, and went into the tap-room, and saw the prisoner with a pint pot beside him—there was no one else there—when he was gone the pot was gone—I told my mistress—I went to the prisoner's house and asked for the pint pot—he shoved me to the door, and shut it—I said "I must have it"—he went back, gave it me up, and said, "For God's sake don't say anything about it, or you will ruin me."

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE Q. How long was he there? A. Not two minutes—I knew the prisoner's name—I believe he works for my father—I do not know his son intimately—I have seen him often—I do not know that he and his father quarrelled—the prisoner lived about a quarter of a mile from my master's house—he has lived there four years—he is a brush-maker—I went to the prisoner's four minutes after he left—no one was present when he gave up the pot—I swear he did not say he was sorry he had kept the pot so long, he hoped there would be no piece of work about it—he had not had beer in it.

EDWARD PALMER (police-constable R 231.) I took the prisoner, and told him I wanted him—he said, "What for? the pint pot?"—I said, "Yes"—he said, "For God's sake, be as lenient as possible; I never did such a thing before, and how I came to do it now I don't know."

Cross-examined. Q. Are these your depositions? A. Yes—I men
tioned about being as lenient as possible before the Magistrate—I heard him say afterwards he could not believe he could do such a thing.
NOT GUILTY .

3051.
THOMAS BEAUMONT was indicted
for stealing, on the 13th of October, 1 purse, value 2d.; 2 half-crowns, 2 shillings, 2 sixpences, 2 pence; 1 five-franc piece, value 4s. 2d.; and 2 francs, value 1s. 8d.; the property of
Angus M'Donald, in a vessel on the navigable river Thames.

ANGUS M'DONALD . I belong to the Dreadnought Hospital ship. The prisoner slept next to me in my cabin—in the afternoon of the I5th of October I had a purse containing two half-crowns, 15s., and the French pieces—I put them into my jacket pocket, under my head, when I went to bed—at half-past seven o'clock next morning I missed them—the boat
swain found this money on the prisoner.

JOHN LORD. I am boatswain. After this complaint about the money. I spoke to the prisoner—he said the money belonged to him—I found 8s., one five-franc piece, two single francs, and some coppers on him—I took him before the captain, and then he said he picked it up under the hammock.
JOHN BOVIS (police-constable R 139.) I took the prisoner—he said, "It is done, and it can't be helped."
Prisoner's Defence. When I turned out it was under my hammock; and it is a rule when anything is found to take it to the captain, but we cannot see him till nine o'clock.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Four Months.

3052.
SOPHIA DOBSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 15th of October, 1 jug, value 1s.; and 1 pair of scissors, value 1d.; the goods of
James Bourne; and that she had been before convicted of felony.

SARAH BOURNE . I am the wife of James Bourne, and live in Brown-street, Greenwich. On the 14th of October I placed a jug and a pair of scissors in my window—I missed them, and asked the prisoner about them—she said she had not got them—these are my scissors.
SARAH RATE . I saw the prisoner take this jug and scissors, and put them under her cloak—I told Mrs. Bourne, and she was taken.
Prisoner's Defence. I only had some chips, which I picked up, and a bit of old oil-cloth.

JOSEPH BUCKMAN . I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former con
viction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY .* Aged 58.—
Transported for Seven Years.

3053.
REBECCA ELLIS was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of October, 4 handkerchiefs, value 4s. 6d,; 1 brooch, value 4s.; 1 bed-gown, value 1s.; 1 box, value 1d.; 1 silver penny, and 1 penny; the property of
Fairfax West.

ANN WEST . I am the wife of Fairfax West, and live on Plumpstead Common. I saw these articles safe at three o'clock in the afternoon of the 4th of October, part in my bed-room, and part in a down-stairs room—I went out, and returned about half-past five o'clock—next morning I missed them—this handkerchief is mine.
ISABELLA M'TAGGART . I live on Plumpsted Common. Between three and four o'clock, on the 4th of October, I saw the prisoner go towards the prosecutor's house—she returned in half an hour.
EDWARD NORTH . I am shopman to Mr. Dunn, a pawnbroker, in Queen's-end, Woolwich. This handkerchief was pawned by the prisoner on the 4th of October, in the name of Ann Ellis, Plumpsted.

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Three Months.

3054.
WILLIAM DAVIE was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of October, 1 watch, value 1l.; 1 ring, value 1l. 10s.; 1 purse, value 6d.; 1 half-sovereign, and 1 5l. Bank-note; the property of
George Webb : and
MARY CRISP,
for feloniously receiving the said 5l. note, well knowing it to have been stolen.
MR. DOANE. conducted the Prosecution.

LIEUT. GEORGE WEBB . I am in the Royal Marines, and am quartered at Woolwich. Davie was in the service of a brother officer—on Sunday evening, the 2nd of October, I returned from dinner—Davie came up to me in the passage, and said a gentleman had been into my room inquiring for me; that he had stopped some time, then said he could not stop any longer, he would call again in the morning, and he had been gone half an hour—I asked his name—he gave me some name, which I have forgotten—next morning I missed my watch, ring, and a 5l. note—I gave information to the police—this is the note—I have not found the watch and ring.

Davie. He was asked if he recollected the number of the note; he said, "No;" but when he got home he said he did. Witness. I knew the num
ber, and it has the initials "J. B." on it.

JAMES PARRY (police-sergeant R 8.) In consequence of information I went to the prisoner's lodgings, in High-street, Woolwich—I went into a room, and found Crisp and a marine, and another woman—the others left, and I said to Crisp, "What is your name?"—she said "Crisp"—I said, "I

suppose you have heard Davie is in trouble; what did he give you last night?"—she said, "Nothing"—I said, "What, this morning?"—she said "Nothing"—I moved the mattress and bed off, and saw five or six pieces of curled paper—she seized them—I caught her hand, forced it open, and found this 5l. note in it—I said to the prosecutor, "What is the number of your note?"—he said, "76116, and 'J. B.' on it"—I said, "There it is"—I took Davie afterwards—he was told by the adjutant of the charge—I said it was a bad job for the poor woman—he said, "She is innocent; when I gave it to her I told her it would be of some use to her by and by."

Davie's Defence. A gentleman called, and asked if Mr. Webb was there; I said no; the door was open: he went in, and remained a quar
ter of an hour, and then went down.

DAVIE—
GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Transported for Seven Years.

CRISP—
NOT GUILLY .

3055.
THOMAS HOBBINS was indicted
for stealing, on the 22nd of October, 1 pair of trowsers, value 1l. 10s., the goods of
William Wil
lans Dixon.

WILLIAM WILLANS DIXON . I live at Woolwich. On Sunday morning last I missed a pair of trowsers from my bed-room—I had placed them there on the Wednesday and had not taken any notice of them afterwards—these are them—the prisoner lodged within about twenty yards of me.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON Q. DO you know him? A. Yes—he is in the Marines—I hear he has had a good character—I have no wish to press against him.

ANN BOXER . I met the prisoner in the street—he touched me on the shoulder, and asked me to do him a favour, to pawn these trowsers for him—I asked him if it was anything regimental—he said, "No"—I pawned them for him—I never saw him before.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you pawn property for strangers? A. I had no doubt they were his own—I pawned them in my own name—I told the pawnbroker I was sent with them—I did not tell him I lived in High-street, he put that on the duplicate of his own accord, because I had lived there, and I have used his shop for four or five years.

SARAH STILL . I was passing Mr. Booth's, the pawnbroker's door, and saw the prisoner standing outside—he told me to go in and see if the man was writing out the duplicate for the woman—I went in and he was (I had seen Boxer go into the shop)—when she came out I saw her deliver some silver and a ticket into his hand.
WILLIAM LEACH . I took in these trowsers from Boxer.

GEORGE HARRIS . I took the prisoner—he said, "I know what you want, for God's sake do not say anything about it"—I said, "You are charged with stealing a pair of trowsers of Mr. Dixon, and I must search you"—he said, "Pray let me go up stairs"—he was going to put his hand to his mouth—I seized it, and he put this duplicate of the trowsers out of his mouth into his hand.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you know what character he has borne.? A. I understand he has been seventeen years in the regiment, and has borne a very good character—I think the regiment will take him back.

GUILTY .—
Confined Six Days.

3056.
WILLIAM SMITH was indicted
for wilful and corrupt perjury.
NOT GUILTY .

3057.
MICHAEL DONOVAN was indicted
for feloniously assaulting
Thomas Philip Davis on the 18th of October, putting him in fear, and taking from his person, and against his will, 16 shillings and 6 sixpences, his monies; and immediately before, at the time of, and after the said robbery, beating, striking, and using other personal violence towards him.

THOMAS PHILIP DAVIS . I live in Kent-street, Borough. On the 18th of October, after twelve o'clock at night, I was going along Kent-street—I was a little in liquor—the prisoner tripped me up and threw me in the kennel—be stooped down, but I did not observe him take the money—it was in my waistcoat pocket—my coat was open—he left me instanta
neously, and when I got up I, missed my money and likewise the pad of my wooden leg—I had 18s. or 19s. in shillings and sixpences—I have not the least doubt the prisoner is the person—he did nothing to me while I was on the ground—he left me directly—he stooped down—I afterwards gave the prisoner into custody in consequence of something told me by the witness Barrett—I am certain he is the man—I had never seen him before to the best of my knowledge—I did not notice out of which house he came—it was quite dark, but it was light enough to see him—there was a lamp not far off.

MARGARET BARRETT . I am single, and lodge in Kent-street, in the same house as the prisoner. On Tuesday night, the 18th of October, after eleven o'clock, I heard the prisoner ask the deputy who takes care of the house if she would trust him for that night's lodging—she said "No," and he walked out—he said he had got no money—I went to bed about twelve o'clock—he came in between one and two, and slept in the same room as I did—next morning, about eleven o'clock, I saw him with a pad in his hand—he went out and brought in a young woman with him, and took a lodging for her—I saw them go out together and they came in with a new pair of shoes, a hat, a new pair of stockings, a pair of trowsers, and a coat—he had gone out in an old jacket and cap about nine o'clock—on the Friday night I saw him at the door in his shirt sleeves talking to the young woman—the prosecutor, his wife, and child passed by the door and the prisoner began to laugh at him, and said that was the man he had knocked down in the kennel off the footpath, and that he took the pad from under his knee, that he might not follow him—the woman pushed him into the house and told him to hold his tongue, as he did not know who might be listening to him—I was afterwards going up the same side of the way and met the prosecutor and his wife—I spoke to him, and he gave me into the custody of the police—I went to the house—the prisoner was having his supper with the young woman, and the policeman took him into custody—the pad has not been found.

Prisoner. Q. Have you not said you should get money enough by this to send you back to Ireland? A. Never—I do not want to go to Ireland—your brother and others say they will have my life—they are all robbers at this house—I have left it—the woman of the house receives

every bit of robbery that they bring in and locks it up—the landlord bought a side of bacon of you for 1s. 9d., which you stole—I did not sell it—saw the landlord buy it of you in the parlour—you lodged in the house from Sunday to Friday.
COURT. Q. How came he to sleep in the same room as you? A. There were ten or eleven beds in the room—I slept on one side of the room, and he on the other side with a young woman.

JOHN MOIR (police-constable M 207.) The prosecutor gave Barrett into my charge—on her statement of the transaction, I went with her to a lodging-house, in Kent-street—she went in, came out, and gave me a description of the prisoner, and the part of the room he was sitting in—I went in and took him into custody—I brought him out—there was very little light where he stood, and the prosecutor said he thought he was not the man, but afterwards, when I took him into the house, where there was more light, he identified him, and gave him in charge—he made no answer to it, but said he thought he was taken for a robbery, which occurred with some girls, a few nights previous—the prosecutor pointed out to me the spot where he was knocked down—it was not more than eight or ten yards from the house where I took the prisoner—there is a lamp directly in front of the house—there was sufficient light to recognize any one—more so than where the prisoner stood when the prosecutor could not iden
tify him—the light from the lodging-house window throws a better light a little way off than close to it, and there is a gas light to a public-house adjoining—when the prosecutor expressed a doubt, I said, "Come into the house and look round, there are plenty of them here"—he came in with me and looked round, and after scrutinizing the prisoner more, he said he was the man.
Prisoner, He did not; he said it was a man a head taller than me that robbed him. Witness. Not after he saw you in the house—Barrett told me that she had seen the pad in the prisoner's hand.

THOMAS PHILIP DAVIS
re-examined. Barrett told me she had seen the pad, when she first spoke to me of the man that robbed me—I told her I had lost one, but not before she told me she had seen it—I had not talked to anybody about losing it—the prisoner was by my side when he trippd me up—I saw his face when he stooped down—I am sure I had my money about me at the time I was knocked down—I had seen it safe about ten minutes before—I had had no fall before I was knocked down to the best of my knowledge—I have no recollection of falling—I am certain the pri
soner is the man that knocked me down—I said at first that it was a taller man, because it was dark there, but when they took him into the light I knew him—the house where the prisoner was taken is about six or sewn doors from where I was robbed—he was dressed very shabbily when he knocked me down—it was not far from a lamp, and a few shops were open—I have often been robbed before—I have not charged several people with robbing me—I have let them go—I charged a man that was tried many years ago in the New Court, and he was transported for fourteen years I believe—I never charged any one but the prisoner with this robbery—a little while ago I lost a 30l. Bank of England note, some sovereigns, and a Bank Dividend Warrant—I went to the station about that—that is the only time—I have 1300l. in the Three per Cents., and have a good bit of money at times—I take very little care of it.
Prisoner's Defence. I know nothing of the robbery; I was in bed at

the time with my brother, and the landlady of the house could prove it; the prosecutor could not recognize me, he said it was a man a head taller that robbed him, but the sergeant forced him to give me in charge; and when he came outside he said I was the man; he was in liquor then; Barrett speaks against me because the landlady would not trust her with a lodging that night.

TAYLOR (police-inspector B.) I know the prosecutor—I believe him to be a very drunken character—he has made, I should say, two or three different charges against people for robbing him, and they have fallen to the ground; he refused to charge them at the station—I think it has been done in a drunken frolic.
NOT GUILTY .

3058.
THOMAS HOLLOWAY was indicted
for a misdemeanor; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 33.—
Confined Six Months.

3059.
GEORGE MOULDEN and
JAMES KELLY were indicted for
breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Caroline Banks, on the 27th of September, at
St. Paul, Deptford, and stealing therein 1 basket, value. 1s.; 12 spoons, value 7l.; 11 forks, value 6l.; 2 knife rests, value 1s. 6d.; and 11 knives, value 1l. 10s.; her property.

HANNAH SALMON . I am servant to Caroline Banks, of No. 2, Stafford
shire-place, Old Kent-road, in the parish of St. Paul, Deptford. On the 27th of September, about nine o'clock in the morning, I went up stairs, leaving the plate basket in the kitchen cupboard, and the kitchen window down, but not fastened—I came down in about twenty minutes—the kitchen window was then wide open, and the plate basket gone—it con
tained the articles stated—I saw the property again in the course of the day at Union Hall.

FRANCIS BEAVER . I am a greengrocer, and live in Mason-street. On the 27th of September, between nine and ten o'clock in the morning, I was at my door, loading my cart, and saw the two prisoners go by, walking side by side, Moulden had a basket on his arm with a cloth over it—as they passed the cart, the cloth blew off, and I saw that the basket contained plate—I told the witness Brown to go and fetch a policeman—they must have heard me, for they walked on pretty sharp—Brown followed them up the road.

JOHN BROWN . I live in Mason-street. On the 27th of September, between nine and ten o'clock, Mr. Beaver called my attention to the two prisoners—Moulden had a basket with him—I could not see what was in it—they went over a field, towards London—I followed, and when I got into the Kent-road I was before them—I walked towards London, and looked out for a policeman—they followed me a short distance—when they came to the canal-bridge they met two more boys, who joined them—I continued walking till I got to the Green Man—I there saw a constable, and told him what I had observed, and saw him take the two prisoners and one of the others into custody.

JOHN WHITLAMB (police-constable M 89.) I was on duty on the 27th of September, in the Old Kent-road—In consequence of what Brown said to me I apprehended Moulden—he was carrying this basket of plate in his

right hand, covered with this handkerchief, and a stick in his left hand, walking towards London—I asked what he had got there—he said what he had got was his own, that he had found it, and I had nothing to do with it.

Moulden. I did not say it was my own—I said I picked it up. Wit
ness. He said what I have stated—he resisted, knocked the basket out of my hand, and ran away a short distance—I pursued and caught him again.

WILLIAM FENSOM (police-constable M 204.) I was on duty in the Old Kent-road on the 27th of September, and saw the two prisoners and another boy coming up together towards the gate—when they came near the gate Kelly and the other boy crossed over the road and ran away, and Moulden went up towards the gate—this was a mile or more from Mason-street—I ran after Kelly and the others, and caught them—I asked what they ran for—they made no answer—I took them to the station—Kelly there said that he and Moulden went into a field together, and there found the pro
perty, along with a knife-box and some knives, which they left behind them—that he and Moulden were in company together, and the other boy had nothing to do with it—no knives were found.

HANNAH SALMON (re-examined.) These are Miss Bank's property—they are worth 15l.—she lives about twenty yards from Mason-street—the area-gate was left unlocked, and they came in that way, down theara steps—the initials "H. B." are on the plate—it belonged to Miss Bank's father—I have been in the habit of using them, and this is the basket in which they were lost.
Moulden's Defence. I found them.

Kelly's Defence. We were going to Deptford dock-yard to get a shlip—I saw a parcel lying in the corner of the field covered with an apron—I called Moulden—he uncovered it, and said, "I will take them home, they will be handy—you can carry this basket and the knives"—I said I should not carry any of them, and left them there.

MOULDEN*—
GUILTY . Aged 15.

KELLY*—
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Ten Years.

3060.
GEORGE BENTLIFFE was indicted
for stealing, on the 6th of October, 1 coat, value 5l., the goods of
John Smith; and that be had been before convicted of felony.

JOHN DARTNALL . I am coachman to Mr. John Smith. On the 8th of October my coat was on the box of my master's carriage, in the London-road—about twenty minutes to seven in the evening I had occasion to get off the box to buy some glass, and left my coat quite safe—I got on my box again, in about two minutes, and did not miss it till I got into Hart-street, Long Acre—this is it.
Prisoner. He said at the office, that he did not know whether it dropped or not. Witness. I am certain I never dropped it—it could not have dropped off the box.

JAMES BROOK . I am a policeman. I was on duty in the Waterloo-road at a quarter before seven o'clock on Saturday evening, 8th of October, and saw the prisoner with this coat on his back—he crossed the road walkmg—I asked where he got it from—he made no answer—I took him in charge.
Prisoner's Defence. I saw the coat lying in the road, took it up, and put it on, and was going to take it to the station.

JAMES CUDDY . I am a policeman. I produce a certificate of the pri
soner's former conviction, which I got from the office of the clerk of the Peace for Surrey—(read.) I am certain he is the man—I was present at his trial.

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Transported for Seven Years.

3061.
JULIA COLLINS was indicted
for stealing, on the 11th of October, at St. George-the-Martyr, Southwark, 5 gowns, value 71.; 1 boa, value 10s.; 1 scarf, value 10s.; 1 shawl, value 15s.; 1 bonnet, value 10s.; 1 pair of boots, value 4s.; 1 tea-caddy, value 5s.; 1 cap, value 2s,; and 5 yards of calico, value 4s.; the goods of
James Mason, her master, in his dwelling-house; and afterwards about the hour of two in the night, feloniously and burglarously breaking out of the said dwelling-house: to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Transported for Ten Years.

3062.
JANE BOWLER was indicted
for the wilful murder of
Joseph Bowler.

JAMES COULTHRED . I am a surgeon in the Navy, and reside in Melton
terrace, Southwark-bridge-road—I attended the deceased several times during his life—I did so about six years ago, and have attended the family many years—on Saturday, the 17th of September, about ten o'clock, I was called in—he was then dead—he had been dead, I think, about au hour—a spot on the floor was pointed out to me—there were faces and a good deal of mucus on it, by the side of the bed—he was on the bed when I first saw him—(I had attended the prisoner in her confinement, between two and three months ago, I am not quite sure)—I opened the body of the deceased on the Monday—the cavity of the thorax was quite healthy, and all the viscera—the stomach was opened, and a portion of white powder was seen at the bottom of it, about two inches in length, and an inch in breadth, and a good deal of fluid—the intestines were all empty—the kidneys were larger than they should be—all the rest of the viscera were healthy—we took home the contents of the stomach, and examined it by analysis—I examined it by different tests—it turned out to be arsenic—I should suppose, there must have been about twenty grains of white oxide, commonly called arseni
ous acid—it is generally called white arsenic—if you purchase it in the shops it is called arsenic—I should say the deceased must have suffered very much indeed, they described him to be in a fit when they called me—I should think, from the appearances, the poison must have been taken into the stomach about six or seven hours—I consider twelve hours to be the extent of time within which it must have been administered—I think he would have died in less than that; but I have given the extent—I found some castor-oil in the stomach—I attribute the death of the deceased to the arsenic—I had said to the prisoner that I thought it would be proper to have him opened, they had better send for the beadle; and she express
ed a wish to have him opened—she said that he had eaten apple-pudding on the Wednesday previous to the Saturday, and that he went into the yard and immediately cast it up again—she gave me what she said was some of the crust of the pudding—it was analysed, but there was no arsenic in

that—if there had been arsenic in the pudding taken on Wednesday I should have supposed it had been all cast up again—the people in the house told me he had been ill from the Wednesday till the Saturday—Mrs. Bowler said nothing to me about that—all that I believe she said to me was, that she wished to have him opened—I do not recollect anything more—I was in my shop on the Thursday morning before, at nine o'clock—I did not see her there then—I did not sell her any tincture of rhubarb that morning—I did not give her any advice—I had not seen her from the time I left her when she was confined.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN Q. Are you a member of the College of Surgeons? A. No—I am a surgeon of the Navy—I attended the prisoner in both her confinements—the last was between two and three month ago—her two children are living—she is in my debt for my attendance on both occasions—she has not paid me the expenses of her first or her last confinement—she always paid me the fee, but not the bill for medicine, on either occasion—they have been sent in—before she was confined she said, "I will call some day and pay your bill"—I never asked her for it—I had sent in the bill, and she excused herself on one occasion for not paying the last—I took the contents of the stomach home, and subjected them to the usual tests—I reduced the arsenic into the metallic form, by the black flux—I have no doubt at all the stomach contained arsenic—I also tried it by Marks' apparatus—I was assisted in making the analysis by my assistant Wevell—he is not here—he was before the Coroner, and ex
amined—he serves customers who come to our shop—the crust of pudding which was given me, was not what was rejected by the deceased's stomach on Wednesday—I had no means or opportunity of examining that—one of the earliest symptoms following taking of arsenic is violent sickness, and it is frequently cast up, if it is a largish quantity, with scarcely any injury—I think arsenic was taken on the Wednesday, and rejected from the stomach—I should say it might be incorporated in the fruit of the pudding, and not in the crust; or it might be taken independently, and food being taken at the same time, would be thrown up, by the action of the poison on the stomach—castor oil is a very powerful counter-irritant—it is no antidote—it would certainly be likely to lessen the acrimony of the poison, and carry it off the stomach, by its purgative qualities—it is impossible to say at what time the arsenic might have been taken—I should say twelve hours is the extent—I do not remember stating, shortly after this matter occurred, that it was im
possible to tell that it might not have been taken, some days—I am sure I did not say, "There is nothing in its not having acted immediately, in a hot climate; in the East Indies a man might hare arsenic in his stomach six days"—I said nothing of the sort—I never mentioned the East Indies—the prisoner did not, in the conversation I had with her on the Satur
day, tell me that she got the rhubarb from my assistant—at the time of the Coroner's inquest she said that he had served her—I do not know what day that was—I was not in Court at the time.

MR. PAYNE. Q. How much did they owe you for medicine? A. Not more than 2l. or 3l.—I should not have objected to go if I had been sent for—if the quantity of poison I found in the stomach had been admi
nistered on the Wednesday, it would have occasioned death earlier than the Saturday.

SARAH MORLEY . At the time I was examined I lived in Union-street, Borough; I knew the deceased by living in the same house for seventeen weeks. On the Sunday before the Saturday on which he died, the pri
soner was in my room, and our conversation began about the newspaper—I told her a lady and gentleman and their servant had been poisoned with arsenic, by their daughter—she asked me whether I knew how they sold it, I whether in liquid or powder—nothing was said about the name it was called by—I saw the deceased on the morning he died—I cannot tell what time, it was before dinner—he was sick when 1 first went into the room—he brought something up, but what I do not know—the prisoner was there at that time—she said he brought up every thing she gave him—I asked her why she did not have a doctor—she said, "We owe money"—I said, "Why, there are parish doctors and dispensary doctors; why not have a doctor?"—the deceased said, "Why not me have a doctor?"—she said, "You don't want to be physicked and tortured about"—he had his hand on his chest—I did not hear him complain of anything at that time—on the Monday after the Saturday on which he died I was conversing with Mrs. Parfitt, whom Mrs. Bowler calls her mother—Mrs. Bowler was present—I told her that he had said, "Why not have a docto?"—she said, "He did not say so; and if you say that, you will hang me, for you will be called on the Jury"—on the Sunday morning the day after his death, I was clean
ing the room, after laying him out, and brought a half-pint mug off the drawers' in the room, and took it into the kitchen—there was some tea in it—I emptied it in the yard, on the stones by the water-closet—I saw a sort of sediment in the bottom of the mug, of a dirty white, like magnesia—I then took the mug up stain to my husband, to show him—he told me to take it down and place it in the kitchen, and I did so—I did not wash it out—I never saw it afterwards—a man named Dunster lodged in the house—Mrs. Bowler told me at one time, just before Mr. Bowler's death, that if he (Dunster) got married to the young woman be was paying bis addresses to, she would destroy their happiness—on one occasion, previous to Mr. Bowler's death, she told me that Dunster would stop five years for her—I never saw her and Dunster go out together.

Cross-examined. Q. The prisoner was of a very cheerful and lively disposition, was she not? A. Yes—I cannot say whether the observa
tions about Dunster were made in a joking way—she was not joking at the time, she was speaking very serious—I did not attach any im
portance to them—I had no conversation with her husband about it—I cannot say whether the prisoner was left an orphan, and brought up by Mr. Parfitt—I believe she was left there for the purpose of looking after the lodgers—I have had no conversation at all about this matter with any one—I am a stranger in the neighbourhood—I know Mrs. Clark and Mrs. Jones by coming on the Jury—I have had no conversation with either of them about this matter at any time—I had not seen them till I came here—we came together as witnesses—we have had no conversation as to what we were to say—I cannot remember any conversational all, either before we went before the Coroner, or since—my husband had read in the newspaper about the lady and gentleman being poisoned, and had told me of it—the newspaper was not before me—I told the prisoner what my husband had told me—I said it was a shocking thing—I do not remember her saying so, or saying anything at all about it—she said it was a very shocking

thing—I do not remember saying that the doctors would not sell articles of that sort—she said she had often known oxalic acid used to clean straw bonnets, that she had often fetched it for her sister—I never heard the deceased complain further than putting his hand on his chest—the nurse, named Inwood, suggested that a blister would be a good thing for him—it was the nurse that nursed her, not him—I do not know whether she was there assisting the deceased or not—I said a blister was a very safe thing, and I believe the prisoner said, "I won't have him tortured with a blister"—she said he was labouring under a bowel complaint—that was what was considered to be his ailment—she said his chest was bad, and that was why I recommended a blister—I was in the bed-room, stand
ing by the bed-side—I do not hear very distinctly—on the Monday, when I was telling Mrs. Parfit that the deceased had wished to have a doctor, the prisoner said he did not say it—I said I knew he did say so, because I heard him—she did not say that I was mistaken, being deaf, nor, "If you did hear him, why did not you fetch one?" or anything to that effect—she said, "If you say that on the jury, it will hang me"—she did not say, after that, "Why, you are so spiteful, you would hang me if you could," or any thing of that sort—Mrs. Parfit was there—I did not hear her say so—I was not in and out of the deceased's room during the last day of his illness—I only saw him twice during his illness—I could go in when I liked—after his death I was left in full possession of the room, and did what was necessary to the body—Mrs. Jones and I laid him out and washed him, and I cleaned the room out—the prisoner asked me to do so—she was then in the parlour, the adjoining room—the mug was left on the drawers, and could be seen by anybody—there was a tea-cup by the side of it.
MR. PAYNE Q. Had you any spite against the prisoner? A. Not at all—I had no quarrel with her before her husband's death—I have no spite against her now—I am very sorry for her.

JAMES THOMAS . I live in Wellington-place, Friar-street, Blackfriars-road. I knew the deceased for four years, his name was Joseph Bowler—he was a Windsor chair-maker—I last saw him alive on the Wednesday morn
ing about ten o'clock at the shop—I worked for the same master—he seemed much the lame as usual then—I heard of his illness—I inquired of the prisoner on Friday at dinner-time how he was—she said he was very ill in bed—on Saturday evening, near ten o'clock, I was at the corner of Union-street—the prisoner came to me, took hold of my hand, and said, Thomas, come to my place, Joe is dead"—she seemed very much excited and distressed—I went to the house, and found the deceased on the floor the green-grocer next door had got him under the arm, endeavouring to lift him up—I assisted in lifting him on the bed—the prisoner was sitting crying on the sofa in the next room—I observed a sort of dark phlegm protruding from his nose and mouth—I saw no glass or phial near him the prisoner told me on the Saturday night, that she had given him some brandy, and had purchased three pennyworth of tincture of rhubarb from Mr. Coulthred's shop, and given him that—she said she had made a bason of gruel for Mr. Dunster, a lodger, and was just going to make one for her husband.

CHARLOTTE TROTT . I am a widow, and live at No. 23, Union-street, next door to where the deceased lived. I knew him well for some years—the prisoner and he had been married about six years—the prisoner told me on the Thursday of his being ill—on Friday I met her in Union-street

about four o'clock in the afternoon—she had a cup, and was coming in a direction from the Blackfriars-road—I saw a liquid in the cup—I smelt it, and considered it was rhubarb—I asked her if she was going to give it to her husband—she said, "Yes"—I asked her if Coulthred said it was a good thing—she said, "Yes"—I saw her on the Saturday afternoon, and asked how he was—she said he was very ill—I asked if he was able to go to work—she said, "Oh dear no, he is not able to get up"—on the Satur
day night I was called in by Dunster, the lodger—I went immediately, and saw the deceased laying dead on the floor—he was about twenty-nine years of age.

Cross-examined. Q. I believe you married a son of Mrs. Trott? A. No, Mr. Benjamin Trott is my husband's brother—I have known the pri
soner pretty well all her life—I do not know that she was left an orphan—I knew her by being there with Mrs. Parfitt, a relation of mine, who brought her up from her infancy, and treated her as her own child—she has been with the family ever since—she and her husband were placed in this house by Mrs. Parfitt—it was part of her duty to attend to the lodgers, in consequence of which they lived rent free—they married very young—it was her own choice, and her friends were all agreeable, I believe—he was a man of a gloomy disposition, and of very retired habits—he fre
quently passed my house, but we merely passed the compliments of the day, "Good morning, a fine day," and so on—we never associated fur
ther—I was not in his company of late, and do not know whether that manner had increased of late—I do not know of my own knowledge of any attempt he has made to destroy himself—I have heard so.
MR. PAYNE Q. How long ago did you hear of any thing of the sort? A. last week—I only heard of it then.

THOMAS LEADBEATER . I am a chair-maker, and live in the Borough-road. The deceased was in my employment—he worked for me last on the Wednesday before he died, the 17th of September—he did not come to work after that—I saw him on Wednesday morning—he had been in my employ eighteen or twenty months this time—I have known him much longer, he was apprenticed to me seventeen years ago—on one or two oc
casions he appeared rather dull, that was all—I did not see him after Wednesday.

HARRIET JONES . I am the wife of Essex Jones, a chair-maker, and live in the Borough-road—I knew the deceased. On Wednesday afternoon the prisoner told me he was taken very ill, with a violent vomiting, after eating some apple-pudding—I sent my son to inquire after him from day to day—I saw him on Wednesday when he went to his dinner, and saw him no more till he was dead—I was present when he was taken off the floor—I saw his forehead and nose bruised—the prisoner said, in the course of the Saturday night, that she wished him to be opened to satisfy the world, as he died so suddenly—I was there till Sunday morning—I washed out a cup of castor-oil and peppermint-water—there was nothing in that—I saw no other cup in the room.
Cross-examined. Q. There was an immediate talk about a Coroner's inquest on him? A. Yes, they said they expected there would be an inquest.

ESSEX JONES . I am the husband of the last witness. The day before the deceased died I saw the prisoner in the Blackfriars-road, opposite the door of a chemist's shop, nearly opposite the end of Webber-street—I do

not know the name of the person that keeps the shop—I asked bow Mr. Bowler was—she said he was a little better, and she thought perhaps he would be able to come to his work on the Monday following—on the Monday after the Saturday on which he died, I asked if she had called it the chemist's on Friday to get any thing to compose him—she said no she had not been there at all, she had been in the road to purchase some soap—she said, in the presence of some other people, that she should have no objection whatever to the body being opened, it would then satisfy the public whether he had poisoned himself or not—she afterwards said the should not like him opened; in fact, he should not be opened unless she gave her consent—she asked me if, in the event of the body being opened, the doctor could ascertain whether there was poison in the stomach or not—I said decidedly he could—that was about the latter part of the conver
sation.

COURT. Q. She did not ultimately object to his being opened? A. Not at all—she said she thought it was quite necessary she should be asked, being his wife—she did not say she would refuse if she was asked—she said it was necessary if they came to do it, that they should have her consent.

MARY MUSGRAVE . I live in Pepper-street. I was employed to none Mrs. Bowler—on the Saturday on which her husband died I was in the house at one o'clock—I was not there at all on the Wednesday, Thursday, or Friday—he appeared very ill—he was in great pain at the pit of his stomach, and was sick—the prisoner was there—I fetched some castor oil with a little peppermint water, and gave it to Mrs. Bowler, and saw her go into the bed-room—I did not go in myself at that time—I saw him again about half-past four o'clock the same day—he was very much convulsed then—the prisoner was there—he never spoke at all at that time, only shook his head—I staid till eight—I did not see him after—I was clean
ing and doing my business in the house—I was not in his room—Mrs. Bowler was in the parlour—nobody was with him then—I asked her when I went away, between seven and eight, how he was—she said he was dosing—I went up at eleven, and found him dead—I saw the prisoner then—she was very much affected at that time.
Q. On what terms did they appear to live? A. There was never hardly any words between them—more of silent contempt, sulky like, to one another—they had no words before anybody.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you attend her in both confinements? A. No, only in the last—she has attended to her two children herself—she had no means of support but her husband's earnings—she went into her husband's room both times when I went in—I had my business to do—she went for the castor oil, and took it into his room—they lived com
fortably together, as far as I observed—I was there for a month—during the lying-in he came home at night regularly.
MR. PAYNE. Q. They did not appear to take a great deal of notice of each other? A. Not a great deal.

COURT. Q. How many other lodgers were in the house? A. Four, with Mr. Dunster, besides the Bowlers—six altogether—one was Mrs. Morley—I forget the other two—they were up stairs on the second pair—one was a widow and two children—the other was a man and his wife—three women lived in the house—that was at the time I was nurse, when
the last baby was born—all these people were not living there at the time of his death—there were two rooms empty.

SARAH CLARK . I am the wife of Henry Clark, a chair-maker, of No. 48, Belvidere-place, Borough-road. I knew the deceased—on the Monday after the Saturday on which he died, Isaw Mrs. Bowler, when I came back from the inquest-room, after the inquest had been adjourned—I think it was after the third meeting—there were three Mondayi and one Fri
day—I attended at three meetings—I did not go on the first Mon
day—I was at the house all the week after he died—the first time I went there was on the Monday night—I had no conversation with her then—on the next Monday I had no conversation with her—I bad only one conversation with her—that was on the Monday before the Friday on which the inquest closed—I do not know the day of the month—as I returned from the Jury-room I called at Mrs. Bowler's—Mrs. Parfitt was there, and she said in the prisoner's presence, "Well, Mrs. Clark, how do you get on to night?"—I said it was postponed till another night—Mrs. Bowler burst out laughing—I said, "Do not laugh, Jane? it is no laughing matter"—she laughed, and said, "Well, if I laugh it it not right, and if I cry it is not right, and what am I to do?"—Mr. Dunster was present at the time—he turned round, and said, "Well, Jane, you ought to know better"—she immediately turned round, and said, "Now, Dunster, you had better hold your tongue, or by G—I will open, and say something that you will not like"—he said, "Well, Jane, I stand manfully before you, and if you have anything to say openly, say it; I will most happily hear you, with the greatest of pleasure"—she said, "I have trusted to one, and no doubt I shall get over it; I am in it, and must get out of it in the best manner I can; there is one thing, they can
not hang me, on account of my children"—she said that partly in a serious and partly in a jocular way—nothing more particular passed that night—we had supper, and went to bed—I remained there all night—next morn
ing we were at breakfast, and the prisoner said, "Well, if he has been poisoned, as it seems he has, he must have done it himself"—she laughed about it—she was partly jocular, and partly serious, middling.

Cross-examined. Q. Did she not at this time say, "I am quite innocent, but they are all against me, and wicked enough to hang me if they can?" A. I never heard anything of the sort—I can repeat what passed from beginning to end, from the time I was there first—I was asked from the Monday at the inquest—I have not been asked as to the evidence I gave first.

MR. PAYNE. Q. I asked you what passed? A. You asked me the last part instead of the first—I heard Mr. Bowler was bad on Saturday night—I did not go till the first Monday after his death, when I came from my work—there was not much conversation then—I remained there till the doctor came—I was at the opening of the body—I heard that he died by poison—I remained there all night, during the week, and I think on the Wednesday, Mrs. Bowler said it was a shocking thing, but thank God she had not done it, that nothing had passed through his body except what she had given him, but poison she had not—I remained there till the Saturday, and she still said that nothing had passed through his body except what she had given him herself.
MR. BODKIN Q. Did she not also say that she was very glad his body had been opened? A. Not to me—she said it in my hearing—I

had known her husband nine or ten years, and Dunster this last twelve months, but never saw him much—I have seen him at Mrs. Bowler's—I heard my husband say something about the deceased attempting to destroy himself—I was with my husband, the deceased, and the pri
soner, coming home from Mr. Bowler's mother's at Lambeth, and I heard my husband say that he had attempted to throw himself into the canal—I did not see him—it is about five years ago—he left our party and ran from the door—I saw him with my husband at a public-house door—I and Mrs. Bowler were at his mother's door—we met and came away together, and were to have gone home together—they left me and Mrs. Bowler behind some distance—my husband went after Mr. Bowler—I did not know what they were on—he went down the street—I saw Bowler go away down the street, and my husband after him—I do not know whether there is a canal near there—I never saw one—I have bees in that neighbourhood I think about twice in my life—I know there is some water by the Bishop's Palace, where I went with Mrs. Bowler to church once—it is the river I suppose—Bowler ran down the street—I do not know whether it would lead him to that water—I heard so—I do not know at all—I was not there—my husband followed him quickly, and brought him back—neither of them were wet—my husband told me what Bowler was going to do—he was not examined before the Coroner—he is here now.
MR. PATNE Q. Was he examined before the Grand Jury? A. No—he has not been examined as a witness at all—he was subpoanaed.

COURT. Q. On this Monday evening, when this talk was with the prisoner and Dunster, had the body been opened? A. Yes, and they said that he died through poison—I should think there was then a talk about who had done it—I did not notice anything of that.

JOHN PAGE . I am assistant to Messrs. Lowe and Hornblower, chemists, Blackfriars-road. I was examined before the Coroner, on the last occasion (on a Thursday, I think) about three weeks ago—I do not recollect the day of the month—I remember about three weeks before I was examined, a woman coming and asking me for arsenic—I did not give it her—the prisoner has since been pointed out to me—she came with the officer—my decided impression is that she is the person—that was my im
pression when she was brought to me, and it is so still—I would not under
take to swear positively to her, but my impression is still the same.

Cross-examined. Q. How long was it after this application to you that you were first shown her? A. Four or five days, I think, not more—about the middle of the next week—our shop is a place of good busi
ness—people come in and out constantly—she was brought to me by an officer—she was the only woman with him—he had been with me before—he had not told me he would bring her—he had inquired of me abort it—I did not expect him to bring her—he asked me if I should knot her if I was to see her, and on that he brought her—I did not say, on first seeing her, "I think I have seen you before, but you take me all of a nonplus," or anything of the kind—the words I used were, "I have seen your face before," not "I think I have seen your face before," but I will not swear it—the officer did not ask me whether I remembered serving her with any thing, or anything of the kind, nor did I say, "Why, I can't tell that"—the officer did not ask the question—she was only brought once—I do not remember the prisoner saying, "Look at me carefully"

or "stedfaatly," nothing of the sort—she said she had never been in the shop before—I cannot speak positively as to every part of her dress—when she was brought by the officer she had, I should say, a straw bonnet on, and a dark shawl—she was not in mourning—she was dressed in a dark dress and a straw bonnet—I remember having my attention called to her before the Coroner—I did not then say I could not speak to her accurately because she was in mourning—I said, "She is in mourning now"—I did not say I could not swear to her because her dress was different, nothing of the kind—I am quite positive I did not say, at any time, that I would not undertake to swear to her because her dress was different—this signature to the depositions is my handwriting—it was read over to me before I signed it—these last two lines are quite right—it is exactly what I said, but it is punctuated differently—(The witness's deposition being read, stated, "I would not undertake to swear to her, her dress is different, she is now in mourning")—that was in answer to a separate question—I told you just now that I said nothing about a doubt of her person in reference to her change of dress—I still adhere to that answer.

COURT. Q. You spoke of a doubt about her person, independently of her dress? A. The Coroner asked me if I was still of the same opinion, and I said I was—and separately I said, "but I see her dress is different; I see she is now in mourning"—I still say I will not undertake to swear to her, but I am still of the same opinion of her as I was before the Corner—I should say it was about three o'clock in the day that the application was made to me for the arsenic—I am not quite certain—I noticed nothing remarkable about the woman—she was in the shop but a very short time, just time enough to ask for arsenic—I refused her—she was not in the shop a moment—she asked me for a certain quan
tity, but I do not recollect the manner in which she asked for it—she was jast there time enough to say so much arsenic, and I said, "We do not sell it"—she went away immediately—we have not very often had applications for arsenic, not for small quantities—we sell an immense quantity in a larger way, to manufacturers, but we very seldom sell it in small quantities—now and then we do, to persons we know—we refuse selling it to persons we do not know—I cannot tell how many customers come to our house in the course of a day—perhaps near a hundred—I cannot say how many in an hour—sometimes more, sometimes less—there is not five minutes without a customer coming in.

JOSHUA ALLINGHAM . I am beadle of St. George's, Southwark. On Sunday evening I received information of the death of the deceased—I "went to the house on Monday morning—I saw the prisoner—Mr. Dunster was in the room—it is my duty to summon inquests—I asked how long he had been ill—she said he had left his work on the Wednesday, com
plaining of cold and pain in the bowels—I then asked when the death took place—she said on the Saturday night, about ten o'clock—I asked why, as he had been ill from the Wednesday, she had had no medical man to see him—she said that he had an objection to seeing a medical man—I asked how long she had left the room previous to finding him dead—(I asked that question to see if it was a case for an inquest to be held)—she said she had been absent from the room somewhere about half-an-hour, she could not be certain, that hearing a fall in the room she proceeded to the room, and found him on the floor—I then asked her what she had done—she said she immediately called assistance, and screamed out—I asked her

who that party was—she said it was Mr. Dunster, that she called him into the room, that he then left for the purpose of calling other assistance and fetched another person named Runn, and likewise Mrs. Trott, and Mr. Dunster then went and fetched Mr. Coulthred—I did not make any search in the room at that time—on the Tuesday morning I saw Mr. Coulthred, but not in the prisoner's presence—on the Tuesday evening the inquest sat—Mr. Coulthred having made the post mortem examination, it then came out that it was a case of poisoning, and I made further inquiries—I saw the prisoner on the Wednesday—she seemed to be very much affected—on inquiry I found that she had been out on the Friday, and I asked her for what purpose she went out on the Friday, and where she went to—she said she had been to the Blackfriars-road for the purpose of getting some tincture of rhubarb, for Mr. Bowler—I then inquired where she got it—she said at a chemist's shop, opposite Rowland Hill's chapel—she could not tell the name of the chemist, she did not remember it, but I have found out that it was Jones—she said that it was at a chemist's shop within two or three doors of the New-cut—I asked what they had bad for dinner on the Wednesday—she said apple-pudding—I enquired whether there was any portion of it left—she said there was—she fetched some of the crust for me, and I afterwards took it to Mr. Coulthred in a saucer—Mrs. Bowler went with me willingly to the different places—I asked her to change her dress, from the mourning dress to a coloured bonnet, and she did it willingly.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you take her to several chemists' shops in the neighbourhood? A. I did, among others to Mr. Jones—the cup, or mug, in which the rhubarb was said to have been fetched, was taken with her—Mr. Jones could not call her to mind at the time, but when I produced the cup he recollected that, and he then asked her what quantity she had—she said, "Three-penny worth"—he said, "How far would the three-penny worth come up to in the cup?"—she then pointed to a certain mark, and Mr. Jones immediately told the assistant to put so many grains of water in, and it corresponded exactly with what she said—this was on the 27th, I think, the Monday week after his death—I went to the house from time to time for the whole three weeks the Coroner's jury were sitting—I always found her at home, and most willing to accompany me wherever I suggested—on the same day that I took her to Jones I took ber to Hornblower's—I had been there before that day, and had seen the wit
ness Page—I asked him if he thought he should be able to recognize her again—be said he thought he should—I intimated to him that I would bring her—I cannot positively say that I told him I would bring hw—I did not say any thing about when I would come—from the conversa
tion he of course would expect me to bring her—she had a cotton gown on, and the bonnet that she said she was out with when she went to get the tincture of rhubarb on the Friday—she herself told me how she bad been dressed on the Friday—she took off her widow's cap and dress and put thw one on—a man named Lowring accompanied us to Mr. Page—she wai the only female—I remember Page saying, when he saw her, "I think I hive seen you before"—it was the first thing he said—I do not remember bw saying any thing about being taken rather at a nonplus—I then asked him whether that was the party that had applied to him for arsenic, and be said he had no doubt that she was—when I first went in, he said, "I have seen you before"—I will not be positive whether he said, "I think," or not—

the woman herself said nothing at all—I do not think she uttered a word—I do not think she denied being the person that had been there—I will not be positive as to that—I cannot charge my memory to say whether she made any observation, when he said he had no doubt of it—she stood some short distance from me—I remember something about her calling on him to look at her steadfastly and carefully—I will not be positive whe
ther she denied being in the shop or not.

COURT. Q. What time of day was this? A. Between two and three in the afternoon, I believe—she and I went away together—I did not return to her house with her—I walked a short distance along Blackfdarsr road with her.

HENRY CLARK . I am the husband of Sarah Clark. MR. BODKIN. Q. DO you remember any occasion on which the deceased made an attempt on his life? A.
