Yes—I was with him at the time—it was between four and five years ago—I have known him ten or twelve years, and worked with him—I was with him and his brother-in-law at his mother's, at Lambeth—I forget his brother-in-law's name—he lives at Dartford—my wife and Mrs. Bowler were there—we were ail together—his brother-in-law came to the shop, and he went out to drink with him—we went from there to his mother's at Lambeth—I saw him outside the door, and he said, "I shall go and jump into the Thames"—he ran very hard from me, direct to the Thames—I ran very hard after him, and stopped him about twenty feet from the water—I said, "Joe, what are you at?"—he said, "I shall go and jump into the Thames, and drown myself"—I brought him away—my wife was there, but not when I stopped him—she was along with Mrs. Bowler—we were all five to gether in company outside when he started—we were, it might be, 400 yards from the Thames—I know of no attempt he made since that.

MR. PAYNE. Q. Had you been with him all the day? A. No—only three or four hours—nothing had happened to make him do this—he was very tipsy at the time—he did not get nearer the water than twenty feet—I think he would have gone into the Thames that night if I had not stopped him.
COURT Q. Was he melancholy, or dissatisfied about anything? A. No, only he was in liquor.

ELIZABETH TROTT . I am the wife of a publican, who keeps the Nun's-head at Peckham—my mother's name is Parfitt—I have known the prisoner since a few years after she was born—my mother was acquainted with the prisoner's parents, and she took the prisoner at her father's death—she was then not quite seven months old—she apprenticed her to Mrs. Coxton, a milliner, and kept her until her marriage—she received a very good plain education, according to my mother's circumstances—she knew the deceased some years previous to her marriage, which took place six years ago in November—she and her husband came to live in my house in Union-street—they came there at my mother's request, to wait on her, consequence of her being very much crippled—my mother afterwards came to me for the benefit of her health, and the prisoner and her husband continued to reside there to take care of her house, in return for which they lived rent-free—it was occupied by various lodgers—Mr. Dunster was one of them—a niece of mine, named Charlotte Trott, is engaged to

Dunster, and has been so some months—I have known Dunster personally for ten or twelve years, but I have known there was such a person this twenty years—he is a first-cousin of my husband's—I knew the prisoner's husband—I never could form an idea of his disposition—he was very gloomy in my presence—I never exchanged half-a-dozen words with him at one time, and I have been with him for hours—he was so reserved in his manner, he never held any conversation with any of us—he was quite of a reserved gloomy habit, and, I should say, desponding—I never saw him merry or cheerful—I have known the prisoner and deceased for many years—they were not brought up together, only for a few years—they came together being inmates of one house.

COURT. Q. How long has Dunster been paying his addresses to your niece? A. Some months—I have known of it since May last, I cannot Bay how long before—I was present on the occasion of Mrs. Clark coming from the inquest, and saying that it was again postponed—that was after the first adjournment—Mrs. Clark stated some observation made by out of the Jury—the prisoner smiled, and my mother chided her for laughing at it—she said she did not consider it was a time for levity—the prisoner directly said if she laughed it was not right, if she cried it was not right, what was she to do?—she had cried at various times, but not that evening, and my mother had cheered her when she was low spirited, comforted her, and said, "Don't cry"—the prisoner said she considered people were very much prejudiced against her, and she did not know for what or for why—she said a great many would glory to see her hanged, but there was one above who knew all, and that was the one she would trust to—she is a person of a good and humane disposition—we have been brought up together as sisters—she was very open until her marriage, and then her circumstances had been so different, that her spirits have been curbed.

JOHN DUNSTER . I am twenty-eight years old, and am a traveller to a commercial house—I have lived in the house where Mr. and Mrs. Bowler lived, about eighteen months—I knew them very well for at least nine years before that—I have not been particularly intimate with them—I know the Trotts, and the other parts of the family—Mr. John Trolt has a niece named Charlotte—I have been paying attentions to her for six months and more, with the approbation of her own friends and mine-our intimacy continues down to the present time—the prisoner had not inti
mated to me at any time any displeasure on her part, to my attentions to Miss Trott—I remember the deceased attempting to destroy himself in Peckham-fields, twelve months ago last May—we had been to the Nun's Head, Peckham, and were coming home together—I was a little before him—his wife was there—we were coming over the bridge together, and he said he would throw himself into the b—canal—his wife entreated him not to do so, and to come away—he said he would not come away, he would not leave, he would drown himself—I assisted her in endeavouring to prevent it—I asked him why he did so—he said he was tired of his life—I thought at first it was a joke, but not afterwards—he seemed very determined—I succeeded with his wife in getting him away home—he was of a very sullen temper—he talked very little—on two or three occa
sions I had seen him in a room, in company with other person—I never observed any thing particular—he was generally very quit—I think he has remained in the room—I never particulary observed—he did not join in the conversation like other persons—I never thought that

he was depressed—he was very reserved—it appeared to me to be his general disposition—on one occasion, about seven months ago, he told me that he had been home to his dinner, and had nothing but bread and cheese, and had been home to his supper and had the same—he then talked of his bringing home money to provide different food, and he had not got that which he expected—he two or three times complained of great po
verty—it was the duty of the prisoner to attend to me, among the other lodgers in the house—I have never said that she was to wait for me, or any thing intimating any intention on my part to marry her, or be ac
quainted with her improperly—there is not the slightest truth in it—I was about to leave the lodgings—I gave notice last May, at least I spoke to Mrs. Parfitt about leaving, because I did not like to live in the house, in consequence of Mrs. Bowler being negligent—I stated as the reason, that I thought she did not pay attention enough to the lodgers—I also told Mrs. Trott of my intention to leave, and complained of the prisoner at the reason, but she asked me to wait until after her confinement.
COURT. Q. Were any attentions paid by you to Mrs. Bowler? A. Not at all—there was no making love at any time—never anything of the kind between us.

MR. BODKIN. Q. I believe you were in the house at the time of the death occurring? A. Yes, Mrs. Bowler's screaming called me into the room—I went in, and found the deceased dead—Mrs. Bowler seemed al
most in hysterics—she said nothing on my going in—I asked her what was the matter—she said that her poor dear Joe was dead—those were the words she used—within a minute or two I went for assistance, and brought in the neighbours within a minute of each other, and Mr. Coulthred also—I was present the day that Clark came in after the inquest was ad
journed—she first laughed, and Mrs. Parfitt and Mrs. Trott called her to account for it, and she said they were as bad as other people until they were found out—I do not know what that bad reference to—I suppose it was merely said out of aggravation—no other cause that I am aware of—I told her I thought she was very ungrateful—she said if I did not hold my tongue, after the affair was settled, she would say something I did not like—I wished her to say what it was, and urged her several times—I did not hear her say that she trusted to one, or that she was in it, and must get out of it—I think she said at the same time that we would all hang her if we could—I asked what we should get by hanging her—I have heard since, that the death had been a good deal talked about in the neighbour
hood—this was a fortnight after the inquest began—the women who have been here to-day as witnesses were in the habit of coming to the home—Mrs. Morley lived in the house—Mrs. Clark was there for a week—I was examined before the Coroner—I was not bound over as a witness for the prosecution.

MR. PAYNE Q. Was there any body besides yourself and Mrs. Bowler in the house when the man died? A. Nobody—I was in the front room at the time, with Mrs. Bowler—I should think we had been in the room together about twenty minutes—I had not seen the deceased from the previous Sunday till then—I did not see him in the course of that day—I heard that he was ill—I did not go to see him at all—I came home on Wednesday at tea-time, and slept there—I was in the house on Thursday and Friday morning and evening—I did not go to see the deceased the whole time he was ill—during the twenty minutes Mrs. Bowler and I were

in the parlour, I was eating a basin of gruel which she had prepared for me—I did not hear the man groan at all—I gave him nothing—I do not know why I said "Not to me," when you asked me if the prisoner had ever complained of my being about to marry somebody else—I had no reason for saying so—she never has said any thing to me about it—the front par
our was my sitting room as well as that of other members of the house—Mrs. Bowler and me repeatedly went to the play together—her husband never went with us—it was by his wish that I took his wife to the theatre—I asked him first—I should think we went twenty times, and he used to stay at home—he used to go on other nights, not with us—we used to come home soon after the play was over, at twelve o'clock, perhaps, or half-past sometimes—we have sometimes gone to have a little refreshment after the play was over—we did not do so at all times—I did not complain of the prisoner's laughing, and say it was ungrateful of her—not of her laughing, but of her speaking to Mrs. Parfitt and Mrs. Trott in the way she did, in an impatient manner—she did not say, "You hold your tongue or I will open on you"—she said, if I did not hold my tongne after this affair was settled, she would say something I did not like.

MR. BODKIN Q. This room was the sitting-room, and one to which other lodgers had access? A. Not the lodgers, but the family, Mrs. Trott and Mrs. Parfitt—it was the place where I am accustomed to have any refresh
ment—it was her duty to bring it to me—she did so on that evening—I had no idea that the deceased was seriously ill—she said he was nothing more than poorly, and I understood that it was nothing more than the bowel complaint—this was in September—I do not remember the day—I do not know that there was a good deal of bowel complaint about then.
COURT. Q. How near were you to the room in which the deceased died? A. In the next room—she went out of the front room into tint room, and screamed, and I went in and found him dead.

GEORGE PARFIT . I live at the Nunhead, Peckham—my wife is a cripple, unable to come here. I have been acquainted with the prisoner from in
fancy—I brought her up as my own child—her father and mother died when she was six or seven months old—as long as I have known her she was a very open, generous young woman, of a candid disposition—she married Bowler with the consent of myself and wife—they were brought up together—he was apprenticed to Mr. King—they lived very comfort
ably together—he was a very sullen, stubborn young man—you never could get anything hardly out of him—he was gloomy as long as I have known him, which was the six years they were married—I knew him be
fore, but not much.
COURT. Q. You cannot tell whether he was as gloomy before marriage? A. No, I do not know.
MR. BODKIN. Q. Was he always a man of that kind? A. Ever since I have known him to be married.
MR. PAYNE. Q. He was a man of very few words? A. Very few—he would sit two or three hours and not speak.

SUSAN EDWARDS . I live in Rye-lane, Peckham. I have been acquainted with the prisoner ever since she was two years old, to the present moment—I always considered her of a perfectly kind disposition, free-hearted, and good natured to the extreme—I knew her husband—he was a very reserved man, rather gloomy, a man of few words, he scarcely spoke unless spoken

to—I saw them frequently since their marriage—they appeared to life comfortably together, as people in their station generally do—I have seen them at home and in company—they seemed usually on very good terms.

JAMES LINFIELD . I live at No. 8, Tibberton-street, Newington Cause
way. I have known the prisoner upwards of six years—I always supposed her of a very humane disposition, very kind, very incapable of such an act as this—I knew her husband—he was a man of very retired and gloomy habits—I had seen them in company together—they appeared to live on very good terms—she always appeared fond of her children.
NOT GUILTY .

3063.
JOHN HESKETT was indicted
for feloniously killing and slaying
Thomas Wellings.

SARAH SHERWOOD . I am the wife of William Sherwood, a wire-worker, of No.5, York-street, London-road. Thomas Wellings was my nephew, and was a wire-worker—on Monday night he was up in my room doing a little work for me—his wife called him down—I went down about ten minutes afterwards, and saw him and Heskett fighting in the middle of York-street—a great many people were standing about—I saw them strike each other—they were perfectly sober—they continued fighting twenty minutes or half an hour—Wellings fell down nearly every time—the pri
soner fell down sometimes—they kept on fighting till they fell—there was a number of falls, I cannot say how many—they fell from the blows—Wellings was the last that fell—he fell with the back of his head against the curb-stone—he then said, "I will have no more," and I never heard him speak afterwards—I was not with him when he went home—I went up stairs, and they took him home as well us they could—I was with him when he died—his nose and eye bled—he lived a very little way from me—I sat up with him all night—he never spoke, moved hand or foot, or opened his eyes—I and his wife went for a doctor about eight o'clock—we got Mr. Gale—he came with us—the deceased was about thirty years old—the prisoner had married Wellings' sister—they were on friendly terms before—the prisoner shook hands with him after he fell the last time, when he said he would have no more.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. When he fell the last time did not they both fall together and the deceased undermost? A. They did not fall together—I was standing nearly close to them.

MARY RUSSELL . I lived with Wellings as his wife—he was with Sherwood, and I called him to his tea—he came down—the prisoner was in the street—they had a few words—they began abusing one an
other and then fought—I do not know which struck first—they both fell—the last time Wellings fell on the curb, and cut his head, and it bled very much—they both had hold of one another and both went down together, Wellings undermost—they were always very good friends—they shook hands first.

BENJAMIN KEMP . I am a chimney-sweeper, and live in York-street—I saw the fight—I was standing at ray door about half-past six o'clock, and heard the prisoner and deceased's wife, as I thought, talking about fighting—the prisoner said he would fight him when he liked—with that the deceased's wife went and called the other man down stairs, and said, "Come down stairs and give him a good hiding"—he came down stairs, and said, he did not know what he was going to fight about, but if the prisoner, wanted to

fight he would fight him—they pulled their jackets off, and fought the first and second rounds—I did not see a blow struck either way—some blows were struck in the course of the fight—when the man was thrown they closed and went down—the prisoner threw the deceased every time—they were both sober—the prisoner was uppermost every time ex
cept once—the last round they closed and the prisoner threw him, and the back of his head came against the curb stone—he sat up, and said, he would have no more—the prisoner shook hands with him, and asked if he would have anything to drink, but I believe the deceased never spoke afterwards—he went down the last time from a throw, and not from a blow—I should say there were not more than half a dozen blown in the course of the fight—I should say the deceased struck about oneor two blows—his relations and family were all standing about, but they did not not like to interfere—they might have been picked up once or twice, but I cannot say—there were many people round—the deceased's wife got in before they commenced fighting, but she was away again in a minute or two—she got in between them to prevent their fighting, but some called out for her to come away and let them fight—that was at the commencement of it—she at first called Wellings to come down and fight him, but afterwards she tried to prevent them—she stood by the deceased all the time they were fighting—after they made her come away.

WILLIAM GALE . I am a surgeon—I was called in about eight o'clock, and saw the deceased—he was quite insensible, and in a dying state—I did what I could for him—he had symptoms of effusion of blood in his head from a blow behind the left ear, apparently caused by a fall—that was the cause of his death—there were very trifling bruises about him.
WILLIAM KITCHINGS . I took the prisoner—he said he was very sorry the circumstance had happened.

GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined Four Months.

3064.
GEORGE HUDSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 30th of September, 1 metal-cock, value 3s. 6d.; 1lb. 6oz. weight of brass, value 1s.; and 2 metal-plugs, value 2s.; the goods of our Lady the Queen.—3 other COUNTS, stating them to belong to other persons.

ROBERT FRANCIS . I am an Excise-officer. In September, I with another officer, levied on some goods of Messrs. Green, at Battersea. On the 30th of September I delivered the keys to a porter of Mr. Clark's the goods were sold on the premises that day—there was a still and other things—there was a metal tap in one of the casks—I saw the prisoner about—I had information, and spoke to Appleby, the auctioneer's porter—I had seen the prisoner in the room adjoining the room where the oval cask was—I saw a brass tap taken from him—Appleby left him in my charge—I heard something fall—I looked down and found a metal plug close to his heels—Appleby picked it up.

JOHN APPLEBY . I am porter to Mr. Frederick James Clark, an auc
tioneer, and live in May Fair. On the 30th of September he had a sale at Battersea—Francis delivered the keys to Page, and the whole of the things after that were in my charge—I inspected the property at twelve o'clock—it was all right at that time—after the sale, from information, I looked at

the vat, and found this tap had been pulled out—I went up to the prisoner, who was standing on the grussplot—seeing his pocket hanging down with something heavy, I asked what he had got in his pocket—he replied, "A pair of pincers"—I asked to look at them—he pulled them out—I was satisfied he had something else in it—I asked what it was—he hesitated, and then nodded away from the premises, and said it was a piece of metal he had got over yonder—when he did let me look at it I saw it was a piece of metal belonging to the steam-engine, or something of that kind—I took from his other pocket this metal cock—I left him in custody of Francis, and went to my master—on my return I saw something fall from the prisoner, close to his heels—I picked it up, and it was this plug—I saw the policeman find on him this other plug—when I looked again on the premises, the plugs which had been in the vats, and these other things were missing—the number of things found exactly corresponded with those missing, and they fitted in every respect—the officer missed a piece of metal which had been broken or cutoff—when the prisoner was committed, he said he had done it through distress—he said he had a family at home, but be would not say where.
Prisoner's Defence, The articles were in my possession before I went on the premises.

GUILTY. Aged 48.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury ,—
Confined Six Months.

3065.
BENJAMIN SMITH and
WILLIAM CURLEY were indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of September, at
Clapham, 5 spoons, value 5l. 15s.; 5 forks, value 4l. 15s.; 5 sauce ladles, value 2l. 10s.; and 2 knife-rests, value 8s.; the goods of
John Milner, in his dwelling-house.

WILLIAM BROON . I am servant to Mr. John Milner, who lives at Clap
ham Park, in the parish of Clapham—it is his dwelling-house. On the 27th of September, I saw my master's plate safe in the pantry at three o'clock—these five ladles, these knife-rests, and other things (looking at them) are part of them—I missed them at a quarter after three o'clock—they are worth 13l. 8s. 6d.
WILLIAM JAMES FRANKS . On the 27th of September I saw the two prisoners together coming from Mr. Milner's house.

Smith. He said he could not say whether it was me or not. Witness, I am sure he was one, and they were both together—Smith was against the wall—I spoke to Curley, and told him he was dropping his lucifers, and be took no notice of it—I saw them both come from Mr. Milner's—another lad came from Mr. Shepherd's, and another from another gentleman's pre
mises—they walked a short distance, and then commenced running—I am certain the prisoners are the two persons.

WILLIAM WOODWARD .(police-constable P 157.) I met the prisoners at near four o'clock on the 27th of September—they ran by me—I asked what they had got in their possession—Smith said, "It is all right"—I laid hold of Curley, and of another who got away—I then took Smith, who made great resistance—I took the two prisoners into a shop—on Curley I found these silver articles, and Smith had a box of congreves.
Curley's Defence. The boy who got away told me to carry these things, and said he would pay me for carrying them—I thought he was selling them.

SMITH—
GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Transported for Ten Years.

CURLEY—
GUILTY .* Aged 15.—
Transported for Ten Years.—Ship.

3066.
CHARLES ALLEN was indicted
for feloniously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Thomas Frankcombe, on the 16th of Octo
ber, at St. George-the-Martyr, Southwark, and stealing therein, 1 gown, value 10s.; 1 shirt, value 3s.; 1 shift, value 1s.; and 1 apron, value 6d.; the goods of the said Thomas Frankcombe.

JANE FRANKCOMBE . I am the wife of Thomas Frankcombe, and live in Union-place, by the Queen's Bench prison, in the parish of St. George-the-Martyr—it is our dwelling-house. On Sunday evening, the 16th of October I left home about twenty minutes past eight o'clock—I locked the door—I returned in a quarter of an hour, and found the door had been opened, and was bolted inside—I gave an alarm—I looked up stairs, saw a light, and the shadow of a man—I went for a policeman—when I got in I found these things taken from one box, and placed on the lid of another—the policeman burst the door open.

THOMAS FRANKCOMBE . In consequence of information I got on the wall, and saw a man getting over the palings between my house and Cooper's—I ran round, and found the prisoner in custody of Cooper, four doors off—I saw no one but him.

GEORGE COOPER . I heard an alarm of "Stop thief," and in a little time I heard a noise in my back yard, which adjoins Mr. Frank combe's—I went out, and saw the prisoner in my yard—I took hold of him, and said, "You villain, what do you do here?"—he said, "I have done nothing."

Prisoner's Defence. There were two or three of us; we had a drop of drink, and got larking; one of them chucked my hat over the fence, and I got over after it. I got it, and wished to get away, as I heard a cry of "Police."

GUILTY .** Aged 21.—
Transported for Ten Years.

3067.
JOHN OTZIN,
MARY DUDMAN , and
ANN CLARK were indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of October, 3 shillings, and 4 halfpence, the monies of
William Mouls, the master of Otzin.

WILLIAM JOHN MOULS . I am the son of William Mouls; he keeps the George public-house, in High-street, Newington Butts. On the 5th of October, about half-past nine o'clock in the evening, Dudman and Clark came, and had half a quartern of gin—Otzin, who was our barman for a fortnight, served them—it came to 2d.—I then saw him take a six-pence—he sounded it on the counter, and put it into the till—he then took. out of the till three shillings and six pennyworth of halfpence, and put it down to Dudman—she put out her hand to take it up—I put my hand on it, and said, "Stop, let me see what you have given there"—I then turned to Joseph Smith, our other barman, and said, "Take notice of what I have taken up here, it is three shillings and a sixpence"—I sent for an officer, and gave Otzin and Dudman into custody—Clark went away, but she went to the station to inquire about Dudman, and the officer brought her to me, to know if she was the other party—I did not observe which of them put down the sixpence—each of them had some of the gin.

JOSEPH SMITH . I am barman to Mr. Mouls. I saw Dudman and Clark in the shop, and Otzin served them with half a quartern of gin—I saw Otzin take a sixpence off the counter, sound it, and put it into the till—he took out some change, and put it on the counter to them—I did not

see at that time what he took out—my young master came forwards, put his hand on it, and took the change up—Dudman had put her hand slightly towards it, but did not take it—my master took up three shillings and six pennyworth of coppers—I went for the officer.

JAMES BRADDICK (police-sergeant A 30.) I saw Dudman and Clark go to Mr. Mouls' for the first time, on the 27th of September—they both went in—Clark put down a mug, Otzin put a pint of beer into it, and Clark put down 1s.—I saw Dudman and Clark several times together, be
tween the 27th of September and the 5th of October—I watched them go into Mr. Mouls' eight times one Saturday night, before the 5th of October.

CHARLES BURGESS GOFF (police-sergeant A 28.) I know Dudman and Clark—I have seen them together—on Saturday, the 1st of October, I saw them go in and out of the prosecutor's house several times—Otzin was in the house, and served them once.

Otzin's Defence. The way I account for the 3s. 6d. being on the counter is, Dudman called for half a quartern of gin, and gave me a shilling; and then I understood her to say, "Give me that shilling back, and I will give you half-a-crown." I took that shilling up, and the change. I discovered it, and was going to take it up to rectify it, as Mr. Moul's clapped hit hand on it.

Clark's Defence. I had no knowledge whatever of Otzin. I have been frequently that way, having occasion to meet my husband on the rank at St. George's-road. On several occasions I have met Dudman, and she has asked me to drink, and on this occasion I did so; it was a shilling that was given.

OTZIN—
GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Transported for Seven Years.

DUDMAN—
GUILTY . Aged 30.

CLARK—
GUILTY , Aged 24.
Confined Six Months.

3068.
HENRY ARTIFOLD was indicted
for embezzling 1l., the monies of
Stephen Townsend, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Four Months.

3069.
HENRY JACKSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 29th of September, 1 turkey, value 6s.; the goods of
William Gould.
MR. BODKIN conducted the Prosecution,

JOHN WILSON . I am baliff to Messrs. Jupp, and live on Norwood-green—the prisoner was employed with two others in unloading manure on Wednesday, the 28th of September—they came again on Thursday, between ten and twelve o'clock in the morning, and went away again down Norwood-lane, in the direction of their homes—I looked after them—they separated—two of them turned into the foot path—the prisoner went in the direction where some turkeys were, within about forty yards of them—I am sure he parted from the other two—I then lost sight of him—soon after I went in the direction he had gone—I saw some turkeys there—the prisoner was then gone, but I saw him again in about ten minutes, following his brothers—I then found some feathers, which appeared to have come from the turkey.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY Q. When you saw them go along the lane you could not see the turkeys? A. They were going the same way that I had seen the turkeys go along the lane—the men went two hundred yards down the lane before they were out of my sight—they then parted, two turned, and the prisoner went further down the lane—I saw the prisoner join the other two again as they were going gently along the path.
MR. BODKIN. Q. Was there time before he joined them again to go where the turkeys were? A. Yes.

MARY GOULD . I am the wife of William Gould. I had some turkeys safe, I counted them on the evening of Wednesday, the 28th of September—I missed one about one o'clock on Thursday—I went into Norwood-lane, and found a quantity of feathers lying there—they had the same ap
pearance as the feathers of my bird—I afterwards saw the head, neck, and legs—I am quite sure they belonged to my bird.

Cross-examined. Q. Were not your turkeys right on Thursday after
noon? A. No, I had only twenty-eight then—I never said they were safe then—the head I saw I believe was the head of my turkey—I believe these to be the feathers of my turkey.

THOMAS ROBERTS (police-constable S 131.) In consequence of informa
tion I went to the prisoner's house, at Roxworth, near Harrow, several miles from where the turkey was stolen, on the 29th of September, and found the head, legs, and neck of a turkey—I went into a closet adjoining the bed-room, and found a quantity of feathers in a basket, and some en
trails, and a quantity of congealed blood, in a dust-hole—the feathers were partly burnt—these are some of the feathers from Norwood-lane, and they correspond with the others.

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined Four Months.

3070.
WILLIAM HAYES was indicted
for stealing, on the 8th of October, 1 pair of boots, value 3s.; the goods of
Henry Tatnell, from the person of
John Tatnell :, and
MARY ANN MUNDAY,
for receiving the same, well knowing the same to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c; to which

HAYES* pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 10.—
Transported for Ten Years.
Convict Ship.
JOHN TATNELL . I am the son of Henry Tatnell. On the 8th of October Hayes came and told me something—he took off my boots and ran away with them.

JOHN POULFORD . I am a pawnbroker, and live in Great Suffolk-street, Southwark—I produce the boots, which were pawned at our house by Munday, on the 8th of October, in the name of Ann Thompson, John-street.

WILLIAM SMITH (police-constable M 170.) I received charge of Munday—I asked how she came in possession of this duplicate, which I had received from two young men, in a pawnbroker's shop—she said she picked up the ticket outside the street door, and she had given it the young men, she had not pawned the boots.
Munday. I pawned one pair of boots; Hayes said they were his own.

MUNDAY—
GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Six Months.

3071.
WILLIAM HAYES was again indicted
for stealing, on the 3rd of October, 1 pair of boots, value 5s., the goods of
Laurence Brennan, from the person of
Laurence Brennan, junior.
LAURENCE BRENNAN . Hayes came and took a pair of boots from me.
JOHN WILLIAM BONDFOOT . I produce these boots—I did not take them in pledge.
NOT GUILTY .

3072.
WILLIAM HAYES was again indicted
for stealing, on the 6th of October, 1 pair of boots, value 3s.; the goods
Thomas Hampshire, from the person of
william Hampshire.

WILLIAM HAMPSHIRE . I am son of Thomas Hampshire. About eleven o'clock in the morning, on the 6th of October, Hayes took a pair of boots from me—these now produced are mine—the man is not here who took them in pledge.
NOT GUILTY .

3073.
AGNES KING was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of August 1 basket, value 6d.; 3 shifts, value 5s.; 2 pairs of drawers, value 3.; 2 petticoats, value 3s,.; 6 handkerchiefs, value 15s.; 2 aprons, value 1s,. 3 pillow cases, value 2s..; 2 sheets, value 9s. 6d.; 2 toilet overs, value 3s.; 2 towels, value 1s,.; and 2 pair of trowsers value 5s.; the goods of
George Greenaway: and
MARY KING
for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

HARRIET GREENAWAY . I am the daughter of George Greenaway—I went with my sister Clara to Mrs. Cross in Blackfriars-road, to fetch the mangling on the 20th of August, and I had got these things—Agnes King came up to my sister first, and said, "How is your mother?—she said, "Very well"—she asked her if she would have a biscuit—she said, "No"—she said, "I have got a black gown and a half-mourning one, I will give it to your mother to make yon a frock"—she then said she had a pair of boots, and said, "I will bring them down to your mother"—she said, we were to go with her to her place, and then she would get the things, and bring them along with us to my mother—she took these things from us—she said she was going to her place, and if she did not take these things with her they would keep her—I am sure she is the person.
Cross-examined by MR. CURWOOD. Q. Was she an acquaintance of yours? A. No, I never saw her before—it was seven or eight weeks after that I saw her again.
CLARA GREENAWAY . I was walking home with these things—Agnes King came up to me—I have heard what my sister has said—it is true—I am sure the prisoner is the person.
Cross-examined. Q. Had you ever seen her before? A. No.
ELIZABETH GREENAWAY . I have exainined part of this property, and it is what I have mangled.
Cross-examined. Q. What has been found? A. pair of sheets and a pair of white trowsers—I saw them at a pawnbroker t in Walworth.
ELIZABETH EDWARDS . I wash for Mrs. Cross, and the things I washed were sent to be mangled at Greenaway's—these are part of them.
JOHN COLLINS . These things were pawned with me. On the 20th of August—this is the duplicate.
Cross-examined. Q. What have you got? A. A pair of sheets, a pair of trowsers, and a towel—I do not know who pledged them.

ROBERT STURGEON (police-sergeant M 4.) I saw these children—they pointed out Agnes King to me—I have a duplicate which corresponds with a petticoat and apron pawned at Mr. Cotton's—I received them from Mr. Cotton—he gave them up, and did not attend here.
ELIZABETH EDWARDS . These were also in the basket.

CORNELIUS DONOHOUGH . I produce the duplicate of the things found at Mr. Collins's—I found it at the prisoner's lodgings—I asked Mary King if these things were her property—she asked me to show her the duplicate—I would not—I read it to her, and asked if it was her property—she said it was—I asked if she pawned it—she said she did—I said, "You must have very valuable bed linen to get 8s. 6d. on a pair of sheets"—she said she was in a way of having very valuable things—I asked if she had a daughter named Amelia—she said yes—she then said they were pawned by Amelia.
Cross-examined. Q. Where did you find these duplicates? A. In a desk, among some old papers.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

AGNES KING—
GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.

MARY KING—
NOT GUILTY .

3074.
AMELIA KING was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of Octo
ber, 2 petticoats, value 5s. 6d.; 1 bed-gown, value 2s. 6d.; 1 sheet, value 2s.; and 2 towels, value 1s.; the goods of
Hannah Lowe, from the per
son of
Elizabeth Bryant: and
MARY KING
, for receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c,; to which

AMELIA KING pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined One Year.

ELIZABETH BRYANT . I am living with my mother, in Hertford-place, Blackfriars. I went with my sister, Hannah Lowe, on the 7th of Octo
ber—Amelia King spoke to us, and got my bundle, containing these articles.
HANNAH LOWS . I saw this bundle—it was lost—these are the articles now produced—this sheet was in the basket.

BARNARD FLETCHER . I am shopman to John Grove, a pawnbroker, in Bermondsey. These articles were pawned, on the 7th of October, by a woman—I cannot swear who—this is my handwriting—(looking at his de
position)—I swore, to the best of my belief, that Mary King was the person—I have seen her in my shop.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you swear now that she is the person? A. I cannot speak positively—I have seen her in our shop—that makes me believe she pawned them.

CORNELIUS DONOIIOUOH . I have a corresponding duplicate of these things—I found it on Amelia King—I found this sheet at their lodg
ings, which Mary King said was hers.

MARY KING—
GUILTY . Aged 42.—
Confined One Year.

3075.
WILLIAM TUCK was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of Oc
tober, 1 loaf of bread, value 8d., the goods of
William Gold; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

EMANUELGOLD. I live with my grandfather, William Gold, who is a baker at Norwood. On the morning of the 4th of October I saw the prisoner against our street door—I went away, leaving him there—when I came back the door was open, and I missed a loaf from the bakehouse—I told
the officer, and he brought the prisoner with some of the loaf, which was my grandfather's.
GEORGE CADDUCK (police-constable T 164.) I went after the prisoner—he was stopped, and I took him with this loaf—I took him to the shop.
RICHARD ROADNIGHT (police-sergeant T 11.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Transported for Seven Years.
(The prisoner has been three times previously convicted.)
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, NOVEMBER 28TH, 1842.

div0.p: πThe following Prisoners upon whom the Judgment of the Court was at the time of trial respited, have been sentenced as under.
William John Shaw... 377.. Confined One Month.
Caroline Cottrell... 420.. Transported for Ten Years.
William Tucker... 753.. Transported for Ten Years.
Percival Hamilton Chamberlain... 959.. Confined Four Months, and fined 50l.
Selina Ann Hansell... 1170.. Confined One Day.
